「**Zàn of the Two: Fire.**
**Zàn**, insufficiency also. The **year** is **fixed at three hundred sixty-five days plus one-fourth of a day**.
**Xuán** has seven hundred twenty-nine **Zàn**, corresponding to three hundred sixty-four days and a half.
Its insufficiency is half a day, which is called **Zàn of the Two**.
**Zàn**, pronounced *jù-yí* (居宜切).

**Frozen** ascends to the **crimson sky**, **dusk** descends into the **dark spring**.
**Cè says**: *"Frozen ascends to the crimson sky"*—**this marks the beginning of the yin**.
**Fàn says**: *"Frozen"* is **the utmost cold**; **yet the sky** is **the utmost height**.
*"Dusk"* is **the utmost heat**; **yet the spring** is **the utmost depth**.
**Frozen** is at the **sky’s zenith**, hence it marks the **beginning**.
**Guāng says**: *"Crimson"* is **the peak of yang**; *"dark"* is **the extreme of yin**.
**All things reach extremes and reverse**—since the **beginning of time**,
**Yin and yang** mutually **generate**#38,
**Day and night** mutually **follow**#38,
**Good and evil** mutually **lean against**,
**Order and chaos** mutually **persist**,
**Gain and loss** mutually **multiply**,
**Fortune and misfortune** mutually **contradict**#39—
**these are all the natural principles of Heaven and humanity**.

**Yíng Zàn of the Two: Fire.**
**Yíng**, excess also. Beyond the **three hundred sixty-five days** of the **year**, there is an excess of one-fourth of a day, which is called **Yíng Zàn**.
**One insufficiency, one excess**—**the Zàn of the Two** are what they **produce**.
**Cè says**: *"One insufficiency, one excess"*—**the cycles never cease**.
The **Fàn** and **Xiǎo Sòng** manuscripts read *"Zàn of the Two"* as *"Zàn of the Odd"* (踦奇), and the **Fàn** manuscript reads *"cycles"* (儃) as *"meditation"* (禅); now following the **Sòng, Lǔ, and Wáng** manuscripts.
*"Cycles"*, anciently *"meditation"* (禅), pronounced *shèn* (时战切).
**Lǔ says**: *"When yin reaches its extreme and yang arises, they mutually cycle and replace each other without end."*
**Guāng says**: *"The calculations of insufficiency and excess*#35#36—**even Heaven and Earth cannot equalize them."*
**Only when they are unequal** can **transformation and change** occur, **endlessly generating**.
Thus it is said: *"Twenty-nine days of insufficiency*#27#35#36, **and the moon shifts to the next cycle**;
*Twenty-seven days of insufficiency*#27#35#36, **and it completes the Heavenly revolution**.*
Then there are **the dark and new moons**, **the ten celestial stems**, **the twelve terrestrial branches**,
Then there are **the six divisions of pregnancy**—this is **how they endure forever**.
**The Great Commentary on the *Tàixuán* Scriptures concludes here.**

#35#36*"Guāng says"*#37, *"the calculations"*#35#36—originally missing, supplemented from the **Fàn** and **備要、全書** manuscripts.
#37*"This"*—originally missing, supplemented from the **備要、全書** manuscripts.
#38*"Follow"*—originally *"become"* (成), corrected according to the **備要、全書** manuscripts and context.

---
*(Note: The annotations #35–#38 refer to textual corrections in the original, not part of the translation itself.)*

chunks.original_text: #39『反』原作『承』，据备要、全书本改。 太玄首测冲错摛莹注卷第七#1 襄陵许翰注 玄首都序 正文已在前，序不复重出。 玄象浑天，一阴一阳相 ，而参三之也。 玄有三统，而中以一阳乘一统，生万物焉。 而方、州、部、家，皆有一有二有三，是谓三位疏成。 曰陈其九九，以数生者。 九营周流有虚，设辟以疏，生生而无已也。 赞上群纲，首辞也。 乃综乎名，系玄姓也。 玄首 首文各散在经下，不复重出。 《易》之分卦御历，爻直一日，更六十卦而日周三百六十。 坎、离、震、兑，为之方伯用事。 分至之日又四时，爻直一气，更四卦而周二十四气焉。 《传》曰：甲子卦气起中孚。 六日八十分日之七，此玄经之泰始也。 中孚统冬至初候，所谓蚯蚓结者。 自中之初至周之三，而复受之。 复统次候，所谓麋角解者。 自周之四至礥之六，而屯受之。 屯统永候，所谓水泉动者。 自礥之七至闲上九，而三卦之气备矣。 又卦各有所余，八十分日之七，参差相错而成。 岁终卦以六十而统玄八十一首，气玄涉入如此。 是以卦有重出，盖气数流於天地之间，有艰难系碍而未解，或发挥陨淮而不御，则卦亦象之。 为之仍累而相属，是以二十一首类自相若也。 说者不虚四时之卦，而谓以应准离，以疑准震，以沈准兑，以勤准坎，则亦不察於历矣。 玄测都序 正文已在前，序不复重出。 一日一昼一夜，通乎昼夜之道而知者，日之神明也，故则象焉。 昼则阳推五福以类升，夜则阴幽六极以类降。 升降相关，是以首贞而测变通之。 一与六为北，二与七为南，经也。 三与八为东，四与九为西，纬也。 中五以极，亦为之经。 六甲击焉於其间，而日逆乘之，与斗相逢，斗顺故也。 斗正月以定四时，而日一逢之，三百有六旬有六日而成岁焉。 岁月日时无易而百谷成，故玄测用世，则又用明，俊民用章，家用平康矣。 玄测 测文各散在诸赞下，不复重出。 许解阙。 玄冲

**Chapter Seven: Commentary on the *Tàixuán* Scriptures – *Shànglíng* Xu Hàn’s Annotations**
**Preface to *Xuānshǒu* (The Mysterious Origin)**

The main text has already been presented earlier; the preface is omitted to avoid repetition.

The **mysterious patterns** of the **cosmic whole**—
One yin and one yang interweave,
Yet harmonized by the **Three**—this is how they function.

The **Mysterious** encompasses **Three Systems**,
And within them, one yang governs one system,
Giving rise to all things.

From the **regions, states, districts, and households**,
Each follows the **One, Two, or Three**—
This is called **the dispersion of the Three Positions**.

It is said: *"Arrange the Nine Nines,*
To calculate the birth of all things."

The **Nine Circuits** flow cyclically with voids,
Establishing divisions to disperse—
Life perpetuates without end.

**Praise to the Supreme Principles**—
This is the **opening discourse**.

Now it gathers names,
Systematizing the **Mysterious lineage**.

**The Mysterious Origin**—
The opening text is scattered beneath the scriptures and is omitted here to avoid repetition.

The *Yì* divides the **hexagrams** to govern the calendar:
Each line represents one day,
And sixty hexagrams complete the **360-day cycle**.

**Kǎn, Lǐ, Zhèn, and Duì** serve as the **Four Cardinal Directors** in their seasons.

The **solstices and equinoxes** mark the four seasons,
Each line representing one **qi**,
And four hexagrams completing the **24 seasonal qi**.

The *Commentary* states:
*"The *Jiǎzǐ* hexagram-qi begins with *Zhōngfá*."*

Seven parts of the **80% day**—
This is the **beginning of the Mysterious Scriptures**.

*Zhōngfá* governs the **first sign of Winter Solstice**—
The so-called *"earthworms knotting."*

From the **first day of the cycle** to the **third day of the revolution**,
It is then **received by *Fù* (Repetition).**

*Fù* governs the **second sign**—
The so-called *"deer antlers shedding."*

From the **fourth day of the revolution** to the **sixth day of *Lún* (Abundance)**,
It is then **received by *Tún* (Difficulty).**

*Tún* governs the **third sign**—
The so-called *"waters and springs moving."*

From the **seventh day of *Lún*** to the **ninth day of *Xián* (Dispersion)**,
The **three hexagrams’ qi** are now complete.

Each hexagram has a remainder—
Seven parts of the **80% day**—
Overlapping and interwoven to form the whole.

At the year’s end, the **sixty hexagrams** govern the **Eighty-One Mysterious Origins**,
And the **Mysterious qi** permeates thus.

Therefore, some hexagrams recur—
For the **qi’s numbers** flow between Heaven and Earth,
Encountering obstacles that remain unresolved,
Or erupting chaotically without control—
Thus the hexagrams mirror these phenomena.

They accumulate and connect sequentially,
Hence the **twenty-one Origins** share similarities.

Scholars who dismiss the **four-seasonal hexagrams**
And claim *"Lǐ corresponds to separation, Zhèn to doubt, Duì to stagnation, Kǎn to diligence"*
Fail to grasp the **calendar’s true function**.

**Preface to *Xuāncōng* (The Mysterious Collision)**

The main text has already been presented earlier; the preface is omitted to avoid repetition.

One day, one **daytime**, one **nighttime**—
Uniting the **Dao of day and night** in understanding,
This is the **divine clarity of the Sun**,
Hence its symbols are modeled after it.

By day, the **yang** promotes the **Five Blessings** in ascending order,
By night, the **yin** descends through the **Six Extremes**.

Ascension and descent are interdependent,
Thus the **Origins** are established to measure **transformations**.

One and Six form the **North**,
Two and Seven form the **South**—this is the **vertical axis**.

Three and Eight form the **East**,
Four and Nine form the **West**—this is the **horizontal axis**.

The **Central Five** mark the **Pole**,
Also serving as the **vertical axis**.

The **Six *Jiǎ* (Stems)** strike between them,
While the **Sun** moves inversely,
Meeting the **Big Dipper**—
For the Dipper moves in order.

The Dipper aligns with the **month** to establish the **four seasons**,
And the **Sun** meets it once,
Completing **366 days** in the year.

When **years, months, days, and times** remain unaltered,
All grains flourish—
Thus the **Mysterious Collision** governs the world,
Illuminating the **bright**, nurturing the **talented people**,
And bringing **peace and prosperity** to households.

**The Mysterious Collision (Text)**
The **divination text** is scattered beneath the various **praises** and is omitted here to avoid repetition.

Xu Hàn’s annotations are incomplete.
**The Mysterious Collision**.»

chunks.original_text: 中则阳始，应则阴生。 周，复乎德； 迎，逆乎刑。 礥，大戚； 遇，小愿。 闲孤而灶邻。 阳为德，阴为刑。 德先艰而后易，刑先利而后蹇。 大戚而孤，正未胜也。 小愿而邻，利方生也。 少，微也； 大，肥也。 戾，内反； 廓，外违也。 内戚外孤，而不能微之，则伤。 微之乃能反触，天之道也。 遇灶而肥，张而益虚，则独。 正弗胜，而多故生之。 诸家无也字，唯宋本有。 上，触素； 文，多故。 多故，必饰而曲成之，是以文； 至於系素而直之者，质胜也。 干，狂也； 礼，方也。 狩则来，而逃则亡也。 干而不让，进取之狂，非礼方也。 而君子有时而干，则以救世而已。 《孟子》所谓说大人则藐之，为狂者言也。 来尚徐，亡欲速。 上、干生狂， 、羡生曲。 《记》曰：礼以地制。 自应至礼，尽於王制矣。 而有弗胜则逃，嘉遁是也。 礼、文生於外违，则强世焉。 诸家无也字，宋有。 羡，私曲； 唐，公而无欲。 差，过也； 而常谷。 由羡私曲。 动差而过； 由唐公而无欲，守常而谷，是以养心者戒焉。 唐，大心也。 常，则万世君臣之道。 鲁僖公君臣有道之颂曰#2自今以始，岁其有。 君子有谷，诒孙子。 言常谷之应物以类格，而岁有秋也。 礼退己而公天下，至於逃、唐之运已往，而君臣之方不变。 而后见礼，强世之功。 是谓以退为进，以元私成其私。 童寡有，而度无乏。 寡有，颛也。 无乏，节也。 童，利复过。 度，善持谷。 增始昌，而永极长。 锐执一，而昆大同。 达，日益其类； 减，日损其汇。 交，相从也； 唫。 不通也。 ，有畏； 守，不可攻也。 宋有也字，又守上有而字，诸家无之。 傒也出，翕也入。 从，散也； 而聚，集也。 诸家有也字，丁无。 进，多谋； 积，多财。 狂简扶 ，羡爽差忒，反乎其真，童之吉也。 童以寡有，颛而鲜失。 自童而增，纯德方昌。 执一而达之，以与类交，则至动起焉。 故必有畏，而出羡，差戒夫失，而 、傒保其德。 《传》以为有而为之，则易之者，皞天不宜取诸此也。 从，厥民析物亦如之，发虑宪散道德者象焉。 进而多谋，然无敢设於一之间也，推之以格其至而已矣。 《大学》之治，所以至天下平而乐作者，此其物也。 失方而逃，忘忧而唐，然而常、度未替，礼之功也。 度以持谷，至於极长大同，乃变而减，与物各唫，反己自守。 守又弗固，则入而聚积，庶民事也。 衰周之诗，所谓如贾三倍，君子是识者，与时化也。 贪利既胜，德义既衰，则世所藉以行者，唯饰而已，非底至齐，信之所以昭明天下者也。 是以虚伪疑民，是非相乱，使外眩於凋离，而中失其靖止，天下倾矣。 此君子沈藏之世也。 天下之生，一治一乱，其道盖如此。 释，推也； 饰，衰也。 物将去累，推之使释； 质衰而致饰焉。 推自中发，饰自外设。 人之真，积力久则悬解晖发，时至而不自知矣。 聚，积衰也，故老则戒之在得。 格，好也是； 而疑，恶也非。 好是已定，疑非而或之，好恶着焉，所谓格物取此。 夷平而视倾。 夷则各得其平而自如。 视，相倾也。 《春秋传》曰：犹有观焉。 持平而慎倾，可以修德，可以养生。 乐，上扬； 沈，下藏。 争，士齐也； 内，女怀也。 物止其平，乃乐其发而争其守。 士齐，公之至也。

The **Central** marks the **beginning of Yang**,
The **responding** gives rise to **Yin**.

**Zhou** returns to **virtue**;
**Ying** opposes **punishment**.

**Steep sorrow** is **great**,
**Encountering** is **small desire**.

**Loneliness** is solitary, yet the **hearth** is neighborly.

**Yang** is **virtue**,
**Yin** is **punishment**.

**Virtue** is first **arduous**, then **easy**,
**Punishment** is first **beneficial**, then **obstructed**.

Great sorrow and solitude—
**Uprightness** has not yet prevailed.

Small desire and neighborliness—
**Benefit** is just emerging.

**Minority** is **subtle**;
**Majority** is **abundant**.

**Steadfastness** is **internal return**;
**Expansiveness** is **external deviation**.

Internal sorrow and external solitude,
Yet failing to **subtle** it—then **harm** occurs.

To **subtle** it is to **return** and **touch**—
This is the **Way** of Heaven.

Encountering the **hearth** and becoming **abundant**,
**Expanding** yet **increasing emptiness**—then **loneliness**.

Uprightness cannot prevail,
Yet **many causes** give rise to it.

Families without the **‘also’** character—only the **Song** edition has it.

**Above**, **touching** the **plain**;
**Text**, **many causes**.

**Many causes** must be **adorned** and **curved** to completion—
Thus it is **text**.

When **plain** is **tied** and **straightened**, **substance** prevails.

**Dryness** is **madness**;
**Rite** is **rectitude**.

**Hunting** brings **approach**,
**Fleeing** brings **loss**.

To **dry** without **yielding**—
The **madness** of **seizing**—not the **rectitude** of **rite**.

Yet the **Noble One** sometimes **dries**,
Only to **save the world**.

As **Mencius** says:
*"To flatter the great, they scorn you—*
This is the speech of the **mad**."

**Approach** should be **gradual**,
**Loss** should be **swift**.

**Above**, **dryness** generates **madness**,
**Ying**, **excess** generates **curvature**.

The **Records** say:
*"Rite is shaped by the land."*

From **response** to **rite**, it is fully realized in **royal governance**.

Yet if **uprightness** cannot prevail, one **flees**—
This is the **joy of retreat**.

**Rite** and **text** arise from **external deviation**,
Then **strengthen the world**.

Families without the **‘also’** character—**Song** has it.

**Excess** is **private curvature**;
**Tang** is **public** without **desire**.

**Difference** is **error**;
Yet **constant grain**.

From **excess**, private curvature—
**Movement** errs and **oversteps**.

From **Tang**, public without desire—
**Guarding constancy** and **abundance**,
Thus the **cultivator of heart** takes warning.

**Tang** is the **great heart**.
**Constancy** is the **Way** of **ten thousand ages** of **lord and subject**.

The **preface** of **Ru Lǐ Gōng** on the **lord and subject’s Way** says:
*"From this beginning, the year shall have [its harvest]."*

The **Noble One** has **abundance**,
**Transmitting** to descendants.

Speaking of **constant abundance** in **responding** to things by **kind**,
And the year having its **autumn**.

**Rite** withdraws the self to **publicize** the world,
Until the **phases of fleeing** and **Tang** have passed,
Yet the **rectitude** of **lord and subject** does not change.

Then **rite** is seen—
The **strengthening** of the world’s **function**.

This is called **retreat as progress**,
**Publicizing private** to fulfill its **private**.

**Youthful** and **few**—
**Preeminent** yet **without lack**.

**Few** is **excessive**;
**Without lack** is **moderation**.

**Youthful**—**benefit** returns in **excess**.
**Measure**—**skill** in **holding abundance**.

**Increase** begins to **flourish**,
And **endures** to **lengthen**.

**Sharp** holds **oneness**,
And **Kun** achieves **great harmony**.

**Reaching** daily **benefits** its **kind**;
**Reduction** daily **diminishes** its **gathering**.

**Lip** is **not communicating**.

**Lip**—**awe**;
**Guarding**—**unassailable**.

**Song** has the **‘also’** character,

**Xī** retreats.

**Accumulating** is **many riches**.

**Madness** and **simplicity** support **Ying**,
**Excess** and **brightness** err and **miss**—
Returning to their **true nature**, the **youthful** bring **auspice**.

**Youthful** with **few**—
**Excessive** yet **rarely erring**.

From **youthful** to **increase**,
**Pure virtue** flourishes.

Holding **oneness** and **reaching** it,
Exchanging with **kind**—then **movement** arises.

Thus **awe** must be present,
And **excess** expelled,
**Error** warned against,
While **Ying** and **Rui** preserve **virtue**.

The **Commentary** says:

**Hao Tian** should not take from here."

**Following**—its people **divide** things likewise,
**Unfolding** thoughts to **dispel** moral **patterns**.

Advancing with **many schemes**,
Yet none dare **set** within **oneness**—
**Extending** it to **reach** its **ultimate** is all.

The **Great Learning’s** governance,
By which the world is **pacified** and **joyous**—
This is its **essence**.

**Losing rectitude** and **fleeing**,
**Forgetting worry** and **Tang**—
Yet **constancy** and **measure** are not **replaced**,
The **function** of **rite**.

**Measure** holds **abundance**,
Until **lengthening** and **great harmony**,
Then **changing** to **reduction**,
**Lip** with all things,
**Returning** and **guarding** itself.

**Guarding** yet **not firm**,
Then **entering** to **accumulate**—
The **common people’s** affairs.

The **decadent Zhou** poetry says:
*"Like a merchant’s threefold gain—*
The **Noble One** recognizes this,
**Adapting** to the times."

When **greed for profit** prevails,
And **virtue and righteousness** decline,
Then what the world **relies on** to act
Is only **adornment**—
Not **reaching** **harmony**,
Thus **truth** shines **bright** across the world.

Hence **emptiness** and **deception** confuse the people,
**Right** and **wrong** are in **chaos**,
Causing the **outer** to be **dazzled** by **decay and separation**,
While the **inner** loses its **calm stillness**—
The world **tilts**.

This is the **age** of the **Noble One’s** **deep concealment**.

The world’s **birth**—
**One** of **order**, **one** of **chaos**—
Its **Way** is thus.

**Release** is **extension**;
**Adornment** is **decay**.

Things **approach** to **shed burdens**,
**Pushed** to **release**;
**Substance** decays, yet **adornment** is **achieved**.

**Extension** arises from the **inner**,
**Adornment** is **externally** set.

Human **truth**—
**Accumulated force** over time **hangs**, **resolves**, and **shines forth**,
Coming to its time **unbeknownst**.

**Gathering** is **decayed accumulation**,
Thus the **aged** warn against **obtaining**.

**Format**—**liking** is **affirmation**;
Yet **doubt**—**disliking** is **negation**.

**Liking** is already **settled**,
**Doubt** is **negation** yet **persuaded**—
**Liking** and **disliking** are **fixed**,
Called **formatting things** to **take** this.

**Level** and **flat**—**viewing** the **tilted**.

**Level**—each **finds its own flatness** and **ease**.
**Viewing**—**mutual tilting**.

The **Spring and Autumn Commentary** says:

**Holding level** and **cautious of tilting**,
Can **cultivate virtue**,
Can **nurture life**.

**Joy**—**uplifting**;
**Submergence**—**hidden storage**.

**Contention**—**scholar’s equality**;
**Inner**—**woman’s womb**.

Things **halt** at their **level**,
Then **joy** in their **emergence** and **contend** in their **guard**.

**Scholar’s equality**—**public’s ultimate**.

chunks.original_text: 女怀，私之至也。 公胜，则万物皆相见也。 私胜，则万物各相去也。 务则喜，诸家作喜，许、黄作憙。 而去则悲。 宋无则字。 事，尚作； 晦，尚休。 更，变而共笑； 瞢，久而益忧，断，多事； 穷，无喜。 因有乐有争，以有务有事。 变而通之，为天下正，唯平格之，大人为能任此。 我断则众听焉，而事萃之。 和豫通物，而不可穷者，喜也。 喜必有务，务必有辜，事必有更，更时行而断正胜也。 毅敢而割惫。 装，徙乡； 止，不行。 众，温柔； 坚，寒刚。 毅大用事，装而欲去，若周营洛邑是已。 四方民大和会者，温柔之象也。 盛衰相极，必至之几。 是以上毅敢行，下众豫附之时也，而装在其中。 治当成王之隆极，而图及平王之衰世，装以候时，此周公之所以独见於眇绵者也。 惫止不行，坚而持之，则以定倾焉。 密，不可问； 成，不可更。 敢以毅行则装，而温柔相得于密，以类升也。 惫受割极则止，而寒刚反保其成，以考降也。 密不可间，情也； 成不可更，性也。 情，天性也； 性，天命也。 情则毅而不害，善亲亲也； 性则割而不绝，能生生也。 亲，亲乎善； ， 乎恩。 敛也得，失亡福。 强，善不倦； 剧，恶不息。 睟，君道也； 驯，臣保也。 盛壮，而将老也。 亲而后可敛也，敛而后能强也。 则君道正，居有盛时，为法天下。 既受成#3 ，失剧而反驯，保其得。 则阴以老变，阳以非来，为艰为勤，微之艰也。 诸家而作也，宋作而字。 居，得乎位； 难，遇乎诎。 得位则莫之难也。 而信，诎道致信者也，难则俟时而已。 法，易与天下同也； 勤，苦而无功也。 自中至夷，大人之正也。 自乐至法，圣人之治也。 法唯与天下同，故易。 且非易也，则天下孰能同之？ 勤如天道，劳功无苦也。 道非其时，苦而无功，则就养而已矣。 养受群余，君子养吉，小人养凶也。 八十一首，七百二十九养。 事类之委，有庆者殃。 此群余也，而养受之以为种，吉凶蕃焉。 玄错 中始周旋，羡曲毅端。 碎、文之道，或淳或斑。 中始周旋，道德也。 羡曲毅端，时物也。 中始而道生之，周旋而德反焉。 羡曲者，迷乎周旋之运。 毅端者，守乎中始之外也。 端生睟，曲生文。 强也健，傒也弱。 或傒字上有而字。 积也多，而少也约。 视也见，晦也瞀。 童无知，盛而有余#4。 去离故，而将来初。 童之无知，如见有瞀，虽或晦之，见在其中。 欲昭明者，发之而已。 盛而有余，反寡有矣。 弱而傒强，约而无积，此寡有之蒙，未离於一者也。 去离故而将来初，学所辅也。 大也外，而翕也内。 也进， 也退。 乐，佚逿#5； 古荡字。 勤，蹶蹶。 达，思通； 穷，思索。 宋本作达，思也通； 穷，而思也索。 干在朝，而内在夕。 乐佚逿者#6； 无为之适：勤蹶蹶者，有为之艰。 《诗》所谓蹶厥生者，文王之勤止也。 武王之诗所谓王在在镐，岂乐饮酒，此佚逖之时也#7。 思利变通，思索而未如之何，则有穷而已。 朝气锐尚干，夕气归好内。 诸家作席，林作夕。 差，自憎； 饰，自好。 差，内讼恶。 饰，外见美。 格不容，而昆宽裕。 增日益，而减日损。 驯奉令，而戾相反。 释也柔，而坚也 。 坚如履革，失柔和矣。 音昂，革履属。 黄作。 夷平易，而难颉顽。

「**Woman’s womb**—the **ultimate of private affection**.

**Public triumph**,
Then all things **reveal themselves mutually**.
**Private triumph**,
Then all things **withdraw from each other**.

**Diligence** brings **joy**—
Scholars translate **joy** as *yí* (喜), Xu (许) and Huang (黄) as *xǐ* (憙).
**Departure** brings **sorrow**.
Song has no *shì* (事) character—
*Shàng* (尚) is **pursuit**,
*Huì* (晦) is **restraint**.

**Change**—**mutual transformation and laughter**;
**Obscurity**—**prolonged worry**;
**Disruption**—**excessive matters**;
**Exhaustion**—**no joy**.

From **joy** and **contention** arise **diligence** and **pursuit**,
From **change** and **harmonization** comes **rectification** for the **world**,
Only **level and tilting** can be **mastered**—
The **great person** alone can **bear this**.

I **judge decisively**,
Then the **multitude listens**,
And **matters converge**.

**Harmony and ease** flow through things,
Yet **exhaustion** is **unattainable**—
This is **joy**.

**Joy** must have **diligence**,
**Diligence** must have **remorse**,
**Pursuit** must have **change**,
When **change** occurs, **judgment** and **rectification** prevail.

**Resolute and daring**—
**To temper softness** with **severity**.

**Displacement**—**relocating settlements**;
**Restraint**—**no movement**.

**Multitude**—**warmth and gentleness**;
**Firmness**—**cold and rigidity**.

**Resolute** in **great affairs**,
**Displacement** seeks **departure**—
Like **Zhou’s encampment** at **Luoyi**—this is **rectification**.

When the **four directions’ folk** gather in **great harmony**,
It is the **symbol of warmth and gentleness**.

**Flourishing and decline** reach their **extremes**,
A **necessary destiny**.

Thus, **above**—**resolute and daring**—**actions are taken**,
**Below**—**the multitude follows with ease and harmony**,
While **displacement** lies within.

**Governance** should **peak at King Cheng’s grandeur**,
Yet **plan for King Ping’s declining era**,
**Displacement** awaits the **opportune moment**—
This is why **Duke Zhou** alone **perceived the subtle threads**.

**Softness restrained**—**no movement**,
**Firmness upheld**—**to stabilize the tilt**.

**Secrecy**—**unquestionable**;
**Completion**—**irrevocable**.

**Daring with resolve**—**displacement**,
While **warmth and gentleness** align with **secrecy**,
Ascending by **kindred**.

**Softness tempered by severity**—**restraint**,
**Cold rigidity preserving its completion**,
Descending by **examination**.

**Secrecy** is **uninterrupted**—**human nature**;
**Completion** is **irrevocable**—**heavenly mandate**.

**Human nature**—
**Resolute yet unharmful**,
**Naturally inclined to kindness**.

**Heavenly mandate**—
**Severity tempered yet unbroken**,
**Capable of nurturing life**.

**Kindness**—**kindness in virtue**;
**Severity**—**severity in grace**.

**Restraining** gains **fortune**,
**Losing** brings **misfortune**.

**Strength**—**virtue without weariness**;
**Excess**—**evil without cessation**.

**Vigilance**—**the **Sovereign’s Way**;
**Submission**—**the **Minister’s safeguard**.

**Flourishing** yet **approaching decline**,
**Kindness** must come **before restraint**,
**Restraint** must come **before strength**.

Then the **Sovereign’s Way** is **rectified**,
**Peaking in an era of prosperity**,
**Establishing law for all under heaven**.

Having **received completion**#3,
**Losing excess** yet **returning to submission**,
**Preserving what is gained**.

Then **yin** transforms with **aging change**,
**Yang** comes with **non-conformity**,
**Struggle** and **labor**—
The **subtle struggle** of **aging**.

Scholars translate **struggle** as *yǎn* (也),
Song as *shì* (事).

**Residence**—**attaining one’s station**;
**Hardship**—**encountering obstruction**.

**Attaining station**,
Then **no hardship** can **prevail**.

**Trust**—
One who **conforms to the Way** achieves **trust**,
**Hardship**—**awaiting the time** alone.

**Law**—**easily shared with all under heaven**;
**Labor**—**toil without reward**.

From **centrality to levelness**,
The **great person’s rectification**.

From **joy to law**,
The **sage’s governance**.

**Law** is **shared with all under heaven** alone,
Thus **easy**.
Yet if it were **not easy**,
Who could **harmonize with all under heaven**?

**Labor** follows **heaven’s Way**,
**Exertion** without **toil**—**reward** without **suffering**.

**The Way** not in its **proper time**,
**Toil without reward**—
Then **only cultivation** remains.

**Cultivation** receives **abundant surplus**,
The **noble cultivates auspiciousness**,
The **petty cultivates malevolence**.

Eighty-one chapters,
Seven hundred twenty-nine **cultivations**.
**Matters** of **kindred**—
**Celebration** or **calamity**—
This is **abundant surplus**,
And **cultivation** receives it as **seed**,
**Auspiciousness** and **malevolence** flourish.

**Mystic interweaving**—
**Centrality** begins **cyclical motion**,
**Excess** curves **resolute uprightness**.

**Fragmented** and **ornate** **ways**—
Sometimes **pure**, sometimes **variegated**.

**Centrality** and **cyclical motion**—**Dao/Way and virtue**,
**Excess** and **resolute uprightness**—**timely affairs**.

**Centrality** generates **Dao/Way**,
**Cyclical motion** returns **virtue**.

**Excess**—**confused by cyclical motion**,
**Resolute uprightness**—**guarding centrality’s exterior**.

**Uprightness** produces **vigilance**,
**Curvature** produces **ornateness**.

**Strength**—**vigorous**,
**Weakness**—**frail**.

Sometimes *ruǎn* (傒) has *shì* (事) above it.

**Accumulation**—**many**,
**Scarcity**—**few**.

**Vision**—**to see**,
**Obscurity**—**to be blind**.

**Youth**—**without knowledge**,
**Flourishing**—**with surplus**#4.

**Departure** leaves the **old**,
Yet **the new** is **approaching**.

**Youth’s ignorance**,
Like **vision** amid **blindness**,
Though sometimes **obscured**,
**Vision** remains within.

To **make clear and bright**,
Simply **unfurl it**.

**Flourishing with surplus**,
Reverses to **scarcity**.

**Frailty with weakness**,
**Scarcity without accumulation**—
This is the **mask of scarcity**,
Yet **not yet departed from unity**.

**Departure** leaves the **old** while **the new** approaches—
**Learning’s support**.

**Great**—**external**,
**Contracted**—**internal**.

**Advance**—**progress**,
**Retreat**—**withdrawal**.

**Joy**—**idleness and ease**#5;
Ancient *dàng* (荡) as *tì* (逖).

**Labor**—**stumbling and struggling**.

**Perception**—**thoughts harmonized**;
**Exhaustion**—**thoughts strained**.

Song translates **Perception** as *sī* (思) **harmonized**,
**Exhaustion**—*sī* (思) **strained**.

**Morning qi** is **sharp** and **active**,
**Evening qi** **returns to ease** and **internal repose**.

Scholars translate **qi** as *xí* (席),
Lin as *xì* (夕).

**Self-loathing**—**difference**;
**Self-adornment**—**ornament**.

**Difference**—**internal discord** is **evil**,
**Ornament**—**external display** is **beauty**.

**Rectification** does not **tolerate**,
Yet **Kun** is **broad and yielding**.

**Increasing days** **benefit**,
**Decreasing days** **harm**.

**Submission**—**obeying orders**,
**Rebellion**—**contradicting**.

**Relaxation**—**gentleness**,
Yet **rigidity**—**unyielding**.

**Rigidity** like **leather soles**,
**Loses gentleness and harmony**.

**Sound** ascends—
**Leather soles** belong to **ascension**.

Huang translates as *yǐn* ().

**Levelness and ease**—**simple**,
Yet **hardship**—**obstructed and stubborn**.

---
#3: *Chéng* (成) – *Completion/fulfillment*
#4: *Shèng ér yǒu yú* (盛而有余) – *Abundant and overflowing*
#5: *Yì* (佚) – *Idleness/ease*; *Dì* (逖) – *Ease/comfort*
#6: *Yì* (佚) – *Idleness/ease*; *Dì* (逖) – *Ease/comfort*
#7: *Yì yì* (佚逖) – *Idleness and ease* (repeated for emphasis)

chunks.original_text: 断多决，而疑犹与。 逃，有避； 争，有趣。 进，欲 ； 诸本作进欲行，盖当作迂。 止，欲鸷。 进非 则伤，止非鸷则达。 是以君子其进也安，道悠远也； 其止也厉，德正胜也。 廓，无方； 务，无二。 应也今，而度也古。 应与时行，唯今之宜； 度由数起，因古而已矣。 迎，知前； 永，见后。 从也牵，守也固。 礥，拔难； 剧，无赦。 微阳方动，则虽在盛阴，能拔於难。 独阴绝阳，则其穷无赦矣。 唐荡荡，而闲 塞。 更，造新； 常，因故。 失，大亡； 敛，小得。 灶，好利； 法，恶刻。 礼也都，而居也室。 都非鄙之野，室无都之容。 聚，事虚； 众，事实。 聚以阴收，故其事虚； 众以阳宣，故其事实。 虚则易消，实则难克也。 武王之颂曰：实维尔公允师。 此实众也。 受有牧野之旅，鹿台之财，巨桥之粟，此虚聚也。 也皆合二，而密也成用一。 二，人属也； 一，则天精天粹。 万物作类，其密无间，咸见已焉。 上，志高； 沈，志下。 交，多友； 唫，少与。 锐，鏩鏩； 瞢，剪跙。 鏩，宋音谗。 剪，徂感切； 《释文》： ，割，剪出也。 一作 ，一作剪，宋作剿，音锁。 跙，才与切。 先儒以为，剪跙，行不进也。 以瞢先见，故其行如此。 亲，附疏； 割，犯血。 遇，逢难； 装，候时。 事，自竭； 养，自兹。 亲至於附疏，割至於犯血，此仁不仁之反也，治乱之极也。 遇逢难，务早辨也； 装侯时，谨先几也。 事自竭者，施诸外也； 养自兹者，蕃诸中也。 成者功就，不可易也。 范望《玄·错》末有#8：格也乖，而昆也同。 增有益，而减有损。 成者，功就不可易也。 云宋衷补此。 而或谓陆绩自有成首，今以秘馆所藏陆本考之，无有。 近世宋惟干别得古本，亦缺此五首。 而今本又有格不容，而昆宽裕。 增日益，而减日损，莫知何从得之。 故独删宋衷所补四首，余皆疑，弗敢去，以俟讨论者考焉。 玄摛音 ，张也 玄者，幽摛万类而不见形者也。 资陶虚无而生乎规， 音关。 神明而定摹。 通同古今以开类，摛措阴阳而发气。 一判一合，天地备矣。 天日回行，刚柔接矣。 还复其所，终始定矣。 一生一死，性命莹矣。 天分刚上，则日月五星丽之者，皆其柔也。 仰以观乎象，俯以视乎情。 察性知命，原始见终。 三仪同科，厚薄相劘。 圜则杌棿，杌，音兀。 棿，吾结切。 方则啬吝。 嘘则流体，唫则疑形。 是故阖天谓之宇，辟宇谓之宙。 阖天，宇也； 辟宇，宙也。 一阳一阴，乾坤之变也。 日月往来，一寒一暑。 律则成物，历则编时。 律历交道，圣人以谋。 昼以好之，夜以丑之。 一昼一夜，阴阳分索。 夜道极阴，昼道极阳。 牝牡群贞，以摛吉凶。 则君臣父子夫妇之道辨矣。 故日动而东，天动而西。 天日错行，阴阳更巡。 死生相樛，音交。 万物乃缠。 故玄聘取天下之合而连之者也。 连，章、林作运。 缀之以其类，占之以其觚。 晓天下之瞶瞶，莹天下之晦晦者，其唯玄乎？ 晦字《释文》作膴，音武； 一作晦，云当作膴。 膴； 微视也。 今唯下别本作膴膴，诸家作晦晦。 夫玄，晦其位而冥其畛，深其阜而眇其根，攘其功而幽其所以然也。 故玄卓然示人远矣。 旷然廓人大矣。 渊然引人深矣，渺然绝人眇矣。 渺，宋作 ，黄作渺。 嘿而该之者，玄也；

**Cutting through doubts** yet lingering in uncertainty—
**Flee**, there is **avoidance**; **contend**, there is **interest**.
**Advance**, **desire**—*Huang* reads *yǔ* (迂).
**Stop**, **desire**—*Huang* reads *zhì* (鸷).

**Advance** not **straight**—**harm** ensues,
**Stop** not **sharp**—**clarity** is lost.

Thus the **virtuous** in **advancing** find **ease**—
The **Dao** stretches far;
In **stopping**, they are **stern**—
**Virtue** stands **victorious**.

**Vastness**—**boundless**,
**Endeavor**—**unconflicted**.

**Respond** to the **present**,
**Measure** by the **ancient**.

**Respond** and **follow** the times—
Only what **now** suits;
**Measure** by **patterns**—
**Ancient** ways suffice.

**Greet**—**knowing** what comes **before**,
**Endure**—**seeing** what comes **after**.

**Follow**—**dragged along**,
**Hold**—**steadfast**.

**Struggle**—**extracting** from **difficulty**,
**Severity**—**no** **mercy**.

When **subtle yang** first stirs,
Even in **deepest yin**, it **extracts** from **difficulty**.
When **pure yin** **severs** **yang**,
Its **end** is **unforgiving**.

**Tang**—**vast and open**—
Yet **secluded** and **obstructed**.

**Renew**—**crafting** anew;
**Constant**—**relying** on the **old**.

**Loss**—**great** **ruin**;
**Retreat**—**small** **gain**.

**Kitchen**—**loves** **profit**;
**Law**—**hates** **harshness**.

**Ritual**—**comprehensive**,
Yet **dwelling**—**confined**.

**Gather**—**empty** **endeavors**;
**Multiply**—**solid** **achievements**.

**Gather** by **yin’s** **withdrawal**—
Thus its **endeavors** are **empty**;
**Multiply** by **yang’s** **spread**—
Thus its **achievements** are **solid**.

**Empty**—**easily** **consumed**,
**Solid**—**hard** to **overcome**.

The **Ode** of **King Wu** proclaims:
*"Truly, you are the **just** and **faithful** teacher."*
This is **solid** **multitude**.

Receiving **armies** from **Muye’s** **camp**,
**Deer Terrace’s** **wealth**,
**Jiuqiao’s** **grain**—
These are **empty** **gatherings**.

**All** **unite** the **two**,
Yet **secrecy** **fulfills** the **one**.
**Two**—**human** **affiliation**;
**One**—**Heaven’s** **pure** **essence**.

Ten thousand things **take form**,
Their **secrecy** **unbroken**—
All **manifest** therein.

**High**—**aspiring** **mind**,
**Low**—**humble** **mind**.

**Sociable**—**many** **friends**,
**Reserved**—**few** **associates**.

**Sharp**—**slanderous**,
**Blind**—**hesitant**.

*Slander*—*Song* reads *zàn* (谗).
*Hesitant*—*Zǔ* (剪) *gǎn* (跙).
*Gǎn*—*Cǎi* (才) *yǔ* (与) **cut**.

Ancient scholars say:
*Slanderous* and *hesitant*—
**Movement** **stagnates**.

With **blindness** **foresight**,
Thus its **steps** are so.

**Near**—**clinging** to **distant**,
**Sever**—**drawing** **blood**.

**Encounter**—**meeting** **difficulty**,
**Prepare**—**waiting** for **opportunity**.

**Exert**—**self** **exhausted**,
**Nurture**—**self** **sustained**.

**Completion**—**labor** **finished**,
**Unchangeable**.

*Fan Wang*’s *Xuan* [*Error*] ends with:
**Confrontation**—**contrary**,
Yet **Kun**—**harmonious**.
**Increase**—**benefit**,
**Decrease**—**loss**.

**Completion**—**labor** **finished**,
**Unchangeable**.

*Song Zhong* supplements these.
Yet some say *Lu Ji* originally had **Completion** first,
Now cross-referencing the *Secret Treasury*’s *Lu* text—
**None** exist.
Recently, *Song Weiguan* obtained an ancient text,
Also missing these five stanzas.
Yet today’s text again has:
**Confrontation**—**unendurable**,
Yet **Kun**—**broad and yielding**.
**Increasing days** **benefit**,
**Decreasing days** **harm**—
**Unknown** whence derived.

Thus alone deleting *Song Zhong*’s four supplements,
The rest **doubtful**—
**Dare not** remove,
Awaiting scholars’ **investigation**.

**Mysterious**—*zhān* (摛), **expanding**—
**Mysterious**—**penetrating** ten thousand forms **unseen**.
**Nurtured** by **emptiness** yet **born** of **principles**—
**Divine** and **settled**.

**Uniting** ancient and modern to **open** **categories**,
**Expanding** **yin-yang** to **release** **qi**.

**Separate** and **unite**—
**Heaven** and **Earth** **complete**.
**Heaven** **revolves**, **yang** and **yin** **interact**.
**Return** to **origin**—
**Beginning** and **end** **settled**.

**One** **birth**, **one** **death**—
**Nature** and **life** **refined**.

**Heaven** **divides** **yang** **above**,
Thus **sun**, **moon**, **Five Stars** **adorn** it—
All **yin** **within**.

**Gazing** upward to **patterns**,
**Gazing** downward to **emotions**.
**Discerning** **nature**, **knowing** **fate**,
**Tracing** **origins**, **seeing** **ends**.

**Three** **Principles**—**shared** **nature**,
**Thick** and **thin** **contrasting**.

**Round**—**sturdy** and **flexible**,
**Square**—**stingy** and **parsimonious**.

**Exhale**—**fluid** **form**,
**Inhale**—**doubtful** **shape**.

Thus **enclosing** **Heaven** is called **Space**,
**Opening** **Space** is called **Duration**.
**Enclosing** **Heaven**—**Space**;
**Opening** **Space**—**Duration**.

**One** **yang**, **one** **yin**—
**Heaven’s** and **Earth’s** **transformation**.
**Sun** and **moon** **passing**—
**One** **cold**, **one** **hot**.

**Music** **forms** **things**,
**Calendars** **record** **time**.
**Music** and **calendars** **intertwine**—
**Sages** **plan** thereby.

**Day**—**cherished**,
**Night**—**despised**.

**One** **day**, **one** **night**—
**Yin** and **yang** **distinguished**.

**Night**—**extreme** **yin**,
**Day**—**extreme** **yang**.

**Female**, **male**, **pure**—
**Expanding** **auspicious** and **inauspicious**.

Thus **sovereign**, **minister**, **father**, **son**,
**husband**, **wife**—**distinguished**.

Hence **sun** **moves** **eastward**,
**Heaven** **moves** **westward**.
**Heaven** and **sun** **interweave**,
**Yin** and **yang** **cycle**.

**Death** and **life** **entangled**—
**Ten thousand things** **ensnared**.

Thus **Mysterious** **gathers** **Heaven’s** **unified** **connections**.
**Connections**—*Zhang* and *Lin* read *yùn* (运).
**Linking** by **kindred**,
**Divining** by **patterns**.

**Illuminating** **Heaven’s** **dazzling** **clarity**,
**Refining** **Heaven’s** **obscure** **depths**—
**Only** the **Mysterious** does so.

*Obscure*—*Shìwén* reads *wǔ* (膴), **dim**.
Now only **lower** *bié* reads *wǔwǔ*,
Others read *huìhuì*.

**Mysterious**—
**Obscuring** its **position**, **blurring** its **boundaries**,
**Deepening** its **mounds**, **fading** its **roots**,
**Displaying** its **achievements**, **concealing** its **means**.

Thus **Mysterious** **stands** **distant** before **all**,
**Vast** and **expansive**,
**Deep** and **profound**,
**Faint** and **vanishing**.

**Harmonizing** all—**Mysterious**.

chunks.original_text: 而散之者，人也。 稽其门，辟其户，叩其键，然后乃应，况其否者乎？ 夫为玄者，外稽其门弗应，内辟其户弗应，密叩其键然后乃应，而况不为者乎？ 入之深深，索之益薄，於是玄感应焉。 非玄应之也，至精之通也。 人之所好而不足者，善也； 人之所丑而有余者，恶也。 君子日强其所不足，而拂其所有余，则玄之道几矣。 仰而视之在乎上，俯而窥之在乎下，企而望之在乎前，弃而忘之在乎后，欲违则不能，默而得其所者，玄也。 日强其善而拂其恶，以成德器而已。 若玄，则俟嘿契焉。 善几於道，不足者充而发祥，有余者去而弗翳，是以入于玄之平也。 故玄者，用之至也。 见而知之者，智也； 视而爱之者，仁也； 断而决之者，勇也； 兼制而博用者，公也； 能以偶物者，通也； 无所系輆者，圣也； 时与不时者，命也。 虚形，万物所道之谓道也。 虚形，章、丁作虚无形，宋、林、许、黄作虚无形。 所道，宋作通。 之谓道也，宋、许、黄本至阴阳皆有也字，章、丁无有。 因循无革，天下之理得之谓德也。 因循，林作因缘。 理生昆群，兼爱之谓仁也。 昆、丁、宋作混。 列敌度宜之谓义也。 秉道德仁义而施之之谓业也。 莹天功，明万物之谓阳也。 幽无形，深不测之谓阴也。 阳知阳而不知阴，阴知阴而不知阳。 知阴知阳，知止知行，知晦知明者，其唯玄乎？ 自幽摛万类，至於晓莹天下者，玄之术也； 自晦冥深眇，到於知阴知阳者，玄之道也。 其於玄也，见而知．之，视而爱之，断而决之，兼制而博用，能以偶物，无所系輆，则当时命州而行乎天下，能秉道德仁义而施之业，格于皇天矣。 县之者权也，平之者衡也。 浊者使清，险者使平。 离乎情者，必着乎伪； 离乎伪者，必着乎情。 情伪相荡，而君子小人之道较然见矣。 玄者，以衡量者也。 高者下之，卑者举之，饶者取之，罄者与之。 明者定之，疑者提之。 规之者思也，立之者事也，说之者辩也，成之者信也。 言玄之正，胜人事如此。 夫天，宙然示人神矣； 夫地，佗然示人明矣。 天地奠位，神明通气，有一有二有三。 位各殊辈，回行九区，终始连属，上下无隅。 察龙虎之文，观鸟龟之理； 运诸桼政，击之泰始极焉，以通璇玑之统，正玉衡之平。 园方之相研，刚柔之相干。 盛则入衰，穷则更生。 有实有虚，流止无常。 言玄之齐七政，以象天地如此。 夫天地设，故贵贱序。 四时行，故父子继。 律历陈，故君臣理。 常变错，故百事析。 质文形，故有无明。 吉凶见，故善否着。 虚实荡，故万物缠。 阳不极则阴不萌，阴不极则阳不牙。 极寒生热，极热生寒。 信道致诎，诎道致信。 其动也，日造其所无，而好其所新。 其静也，日减其所为，而损其所成。 故推之以刻，参之以晷，反覆其序，轸转其道也。 以见不见之形，抽不抽之绪，与万类相连也。 其上也县天，下也沦渊，纤也入芦音秽。 广也包轸。 其道斿冥而挹盈，丁、宋作押盈。 存存而亡亡，微微而章章，始始而终终。 近玄者，玄亦近之； 远玄者，玄亦远之。 譬若天苍苍然，在於东面南面西面北面，仰而无不在焉，及其俛则不见也。 天岂去人哉？ 人自去也。 冬至及夜半以后者，近玄之象也。 进而未极，往而未至，虚而未满，故谓之近玄。
chunks.translated_text:
**It is humanity that scatters** **it**—
**Knocking at its gate**, **opening its doors**, **striking its keys**—
**Only then does it respond**.
**How much less** when it **denies**?

**For those who cultivate the Mysterious**—
**Knocking at its outer gate**, **no response**.
**Opening its inner doors**, **no response**.
**Striking its keys in secret**, **only then does it respond**.
**How much less** for those who **do not cultivate**?

**Entering ever deeper**, **seeking ever more sparsely**—
**Then the Mysterious responds**.
**Not that the Mysterious responds to seeking**,
**But that the utmost refinement communicates**.

What **humans** **desire yet lack** is **virtue**;
What **humans** **abhor yet possess in excess** is **vice**.
The **Noble One**, **strengthening what is lacking**,
**Diminishing what is in excess**—
**Thus approaches the Dao of the Mysterious**.

**Gazing upward**, it **resides above**;
**Gazing downward**, it **peeks below**;
**Straining forward**, it **lies ahead**;
**Turning back**, it **vanishes behind**.
**Attempting to evade it is impossible**—
**Silently attaining its place**—
**This is the Mysterious**.

**Daily strengthening virtue** while **diminishing vice**,
**To perfect virtue and instrumentality**—
**That is all**.

**If the Mysterious**, then **await its silent accord**.
**Approaching the Dao**,
**What is lacking is filled and flourishes**,
**What is in excess is removed and does not obscure**—
**Thus entering the Mysterious’ equilibrium**.

**Therefore, the Mysterious**—
**Its use is consummate**.

**Seeing and knowing**—**this is wisdom**;
**Gazing and loving**—**this is benevolence**;
**Judging and deciding**—**this is courage**;
**Encompassing and applying broadly**—**this is fairness**;
**Able to pair with all things**—**this is harmony**;
**Unbound by attachments**—**this is sagacity**;
**Timing and untiming**—**this is fate**.

**The Void Form**—
**The Way through which ten thousand things pass**—
**Is called the Way**.

**The Void Form**—*Zhang* and *Ding* read *xūwúxíng*,
*Song*, *Lin*, *Xu*, and *Huang* read *xūwúxíng*.
**The Way through which**—*Song* reads *tōng*.
**Is called the Way**—*Song* and *Xu*, *Huang* originally include *zhī* ("that"),
*Zhang* and *Ding* omit it.

**Following without revolution**—
**The principles of the world attained**—
**Is called virtue**.

**Following without revolution**—*Lin* reads *yīnyuán*.
**Principles generate clusters**—*Ding* and *Song* read *hún*.
**Encompassing love**—**this is benevolence**.

**Ranking and measuring** **appropriateness**—
**This is righteousness**.

**Upholding virtue, benevolence, and righteousness** **and applying them**—
**This is achievement**.

**Illuminating Heaven’s function**, **clarifying all things**—
**This is Yang**.

**Obscuring the Formless**, **deep beyond measure**—
**This is Yin**.

**Yang knows Yang but not Yin**,
**Yin knows Yin but not Yang**.
**Knowing Yin and knowing Yang**,
**Knowing cessation and knowing action**,
**Knowing obscurity and knowing clarity**—
**Who but the Mysterious?**

**From obscurity, unfolding all kinds**,
**To clarity, illuminating the world**—
**This is the Mysterious’ technique**.

**From obscurity, deep and faint**,
**To knowing Yin and knowing Yang**—
**This is the Mysterious’ Dao**.

**In the Mysterious**,
**Seeing and knowing**,
**Gazing and loving**,
**Judging and deciding**,
**Encompassing and applying broadly**,
**Able to pair with all things**,
**Unbound by attachments**—
**Then timing and untiming govern the states**,
**And one acts throughout the world**,
**Upholding virtue, benevolence, and righteousness** **in achievement**,
**Aligning with the August Heaven**.

**Measuring it**—**this is balance**;
**Leveling it**—**this is equilibrium**.

**Making the turbid clear**, **the perilous level**—
**Detached from sincerity**, **it must cling to deceit**;
**Detached from deceit**, **it must cling to sincerity**.
**Sincerity and deceit clash**—
**Then the Dao of the Noble and the petty man is clearly distinguished**.

**The Mysterious**—
**It balances and measures**.

**The high it lowers**, **the low it raises**,
**The abundant it takes from**, **the empty it gives to**.
**The clear it confirms**, **the doubtful it raises**.

**Planning it**—**this is thought**;
**Establishing it**—**this is action**;
**Persuading it**—**this is eloquence**;
**Completing it**—**this is trust**.

**Speaking of the Mysterious’ rectitude**,
**Exceeding human affairs**—**thus**.

**Heaven**—
**Vastly displaying its divine mystery**;
**Earth**—
**Stably displaying its clarity**.

**Heaven and Earth** **fix their stations**,
**Divine and bright qi communicate**—
**One, two, three**.

**Positions each distinct in rank**,
**Circulating through the Nine Regions**,
**Beginning and end continuously linked**,
**Above and below without corners**.

**Examining the patterns of Dragon and Tiger**,
**Observing the principles of Bird and Tortoise**—
**Applying them to governance**,
**Striking at the *Tai*’s beginning and end**,
**To harmonize the *Xuanji*’s order**,
**And rectify the *Yùhéng*’s equilibrium**.

**Square and round** **grinding each other**,
**Hard and soft** **interacting**.

**When full, it enters decay**,
**When exhausted, it renews**.
**Having substance, having emptiness**,
**Flow and cessation without constancy**.

**Speaking of the Mysterious’ alignment with the Seven Governors**,
**To mirror Heaven and Earth**—**thus**.

**Heaven and Earth established**,
**Thus nobility and humility are ordered**.
**The Four Seasons progress**,
**Thus parent and child succeed**.
**Calendars and measures are set forth**,
**Thus ruler and subject are rightly aligned**.
**Constant and variable intertwine**,
**Thus all affairs are distinguished**.
**Substance and form manifest**,
**Thus presence and absence are clear**.
**Auspicious and inauspicious appear**,
**Thus good and evil are evident**.
**Void and substance surge**,
**Thus all things are entangled**.
**Yang not reaching its extreme, Yin does not sprout**,
**Yin not reaching its extreme, Yang does not emerge**.
**Extreme cold generates heat**, **extreme heat generates cold**.
**Trusting the Dao leads to bending**,
**Bending the Dao leads to trust**.

**In its motion**, **daily creating what is not**,
**And delighting in what is new**.
**In its stillness**, **daily diminishing what is done**,
**And reducing what is accomplished**.

**Thus probing with the *kè*** (刻),
**Comparing with the *guǐ*** (晷),
**Reversing its sequence**,
**Turning its Way**—
**To reveal the unseen Form**,
**To draw the unspun thread**,
**And connect with all kinds**.

**Above, it suspends Heaven**,
**Below, it sinks into the abyss**,
**Fine, it enters the reeds** (秽),
**Broad, it encompasses the *zhěn*** (轸).

**Its Dao**—**obscure and deep**—
**Fills what is full**—*Ding* and *Song* read *yāyíng*.

**Preserving while perishing**,
**Faint yet manifest**,
**Beginning while ending**—
**Near the Mysterious, the Mysterious draws near**;
**Far from the Mysterious, the Mysterious withdraws**.

**Like Heaven, vast and blue**,
**Present in the east, south, west, and north**,
**Gazing upward, none are absent**,
**Yet when lowered, it is unseen**.
**Does Heaven truly depart from humanity?**
**It is humanity that departs from it**.

**The Winter Solstice and the hours after midnight**—
**Symbols of nearing the Mysterious**.

**Advancing yet unexhausted**,
**Going yet unreached**,
**Empty yet unfilled**—
**Thus called nearing the Mysterious**.

chunks.original_text: 夏至及日中以后者，远玄之象也。 进极而退，往穷而还，已满而损，故谓之远玄。 日一南而万物死，日一北而万物生。 斗一北而万物虚，斗一南而万物盈。 日之南也，右行而左还； 斗之南也，左行而右还。 或左或右，或死或生，神灵合谋，天地乃并，天神而地灵。 玄术如此，是以人伦物化，参诸天地，和同无间，而玄为之宗。 夏至致日南在东井，冬至致日北在牵牛。 而斗正四时，各建其方。 日历西陆而东，斗轧东陆而西。 万物系焉，盈则兆死，虚则更生。 夫玄散为一阴一阳，维其运也，左右相逢。 如此，故能神灵合并，而反浑乎玄。 曰天神而地灵，言合并而不相乱也。 玄莹 天地开辟，宇宙拓坦。 拓，本多作祏，章、林、黄作拓。 天元咫步，日月纪数。 周运历统，群伦品庶。 或合或离，或嬴或踦。 故曰假哉天地，啖徒滥切。 函启化，罔衮於玄。 章及丁别本罔作内。 终始幽明，表赞神灵，大阳乘阴，万物该兼，周流九虚，而祸福絓罗。 凡十有二始，群伦抽绪，故有一二三，以絓以罗，玄术莹之。 鸿本五行，九位重施，诸本作施重，宋作重施。 上下相因，丑在其中，玄术莹之。 天园地方，极植中央，动以历静，时乘十二，以建七政，玄术莹之。 斗振天而进，日违天而退，或振或违，以立五纪，玄术莹之。 植表施景，榆与株切。 漏率刻，昏明考中，作者以戒，玄术莹之。 冷竹为管，室灰为候，以揆百度； 百度既设，济民不误，玄术莹之。 东西为纬，南北为经，经纬交错，邪正以分，吉凶以形，玄术莹之。 凿井澹水，钻火难木，流金陶土，以和五美； 五美之资，以资百体，玄术莹之。 奇以数阳，耦以数阴，奇耦推演，以计天下，玄术莹之。 六始为律，六间为吕，律吕既协，十二以调，日辰以数，玄术莹之。 方州部家，八十一所，画下中上，以表四海，玄术莹之。 一辟，三公，九卿，二十七大夫，八十一元士，少则制众，无则治有，玄术莹之。 古者不霆不虞，霆，许、宋作 ，音雩，诸家作霆。 慢其思虑，匪筮匪卜，吉凶交渎，於是圣人，乃作蓍龟，钻精倚神，箝知休咎，玄术莹之。 是故欲知不可知，则拟之以乎卦兆，测深摹远，则索之以乎思虑。 二者其以精立乎？ 夫精以卜筮，神动其变； 精以思虑，谋合其适； 精以立正，莫之能仆； 精以有守，莫之能夺。 故夫抽天下之蔓蔓，散天下之混混者，非精其孰能之？ 莹自度数，晖於诸法，而要以至精者，反乎一也。 夫作者，贵其有循而体自然也。 其所循也大，则其体也壮； 其所循也小，则其体也瘠。 其所循也直，则其体也浑； 其所循也曲，则其体也散。 故不惧所有，不强所无。 譬诸身，增则赘而割则亏。 故质斡在乎自然，华藻在乎人事也，其可损益与？ 诸本皆作华藻在乎人事，人事也，其可损益与？ 人事二字盖衍。 许、黄其作其字。 夫一一所以摹始而测深也，三三所以尽终而极崇也，二二所以参事而要中也。 人道象焉，务其事而不务其辞，多其变而不多其文也。 不约则其指不详，不要则其应不博，不浑则其事不散，不沈则其意不见。 是故文以见乎质，辞以睹乎情； 观其施辞，则其心之所欲者见矣。 言玄之事辞如此。 表赞九度，一一、一二、一一二、二一、二二、二三、三一、三二、三三。
chunks.translated_text:
「The Summer Solstice and the hours after midday—
**Symbols of withdrawing from the Mysterious**.

Advancing to its utmost and then receding,
Proceeding to exhaustion and then returning,
Filled to capacity and then diminished—
Thus called withdrawing from the Mysterious.

When the sun turns southward, all things die;
When the sun turns northward, all things live.

When the Dipper** (斗) turns northward, all things grow **empty** (虚);
When the Dipper turns southward, all things grow **full** (盈).
The sun’s southern turn—
**Rightward in motion, leftward in return**;
The Dipper’s southern turn—
**Leftward in motion, rightward in return**.

Sometimes left, sometimes right,
Sometimes death, sometimes life—
**The Mysterious and the numinous** conspire together,
**Heaven and Earth** thus align,
**Heaven’s numinous** and **Earth’s spirit** (灵).

**The Mysterious Dao** is such—
Thus, through human affairs and transformations of things,
It **harmonizes with Heaven and Earth**,
**Unified without division**,
And the Mysterious stands as its **apex** (宗).

On the Summer Solstice, the sun reaches its southernmost point at **Eastern Well** (东井);
On the Winter Solstice, the sun reaches its northernmost point at **The Ox Driver** (牵牛).
The Dipper **governs the four seasons**,
Each establishing its own direction.
The sun **traverses the western sky and returns eastward**,
The Dipper **reaches the eastern sky and returns westward**.

All things depend upon it—
When full, the signs of death appear;
When empty, new life emerges.
The Mysterious **scatters as one yin and one yang**,
Its **movements**—left and right—**meet in opposition**.
Thus, it **unifies the Mysterious and the numinous**,
And **returns to the primal wholeness of the Mysterious**.

It is said, **"Heaven’s numinous and Earth’s spirit"**,
Meaning **unified yet not chaotic**,
**The Mysterious** **illuminates** **Heaven and Earth’s transformations**,
**Encompassing all without obstruction**.

(In some texts, *zhāng* and *dīng* read *wàng* instead of *nèi*.)
**The beginning and the end**—**profound and luminous**—
**Exalt the Mysterious and the numinous**,
**The Great Yang** **rides upon the yin**,
All things **comprehensively included**,
**Circulating through the Nine Voids** (九虚),
And **weaving fate and fortune** (祸福).

In the **twelve beginnings** (十二始),
All affairs **unravel their threads**,
Thus there are **one, two, three**,
To **weave and measure** (絓罗),
And the Mysterious Dao **illuminates** them.

**The Five Phases** (五行) **originate from the Dipper**,
With **nine positions** **repeatedly applied** (重施).
Above and below **interact in sequence**,
And **the Ugly** (丑) **lies within**—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**Heaven’s Garden** (天园) **spreads across the four directions**,
**Central Planting** (极植) **established at the heart**,
**Movement governed by stillness** (动以历静),
**Time measured in twelve**,
To **found the Seven Celestial Officials** (七政)—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

The Dipper **shakes Heaven and advances**,
The sun **defies Heaven and retreats**,
Sometimes **shaken**, sometimes **defiant**—
To **establish the Five Epochs** (五纪)—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**Planting and measuring** (植表) **cast their shadows** (施景),
**Willow and Mulberry** (榆与株) **marked by their cuts** (切).

**The water clock’s rate** (漏率) **is measured by the gnomon** (刻),
**Dusk and dawn** (昏明) **are gauged at the midpoint** (考中),
The **observers use the gnomon** (以戒)—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**Cold bamboo** (冷竹) **as the tube** (管),
**Ash from the hearth** (室灰) **as the marker** (候),
To **investigate all undertakings** (揆百度).
When the **undertakings are set**,
The **people are aided without delay**—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**East and west as the weft** (纬),
**South and north as the warp** (经),
**Warp and weft intersecting**,
**Distinguishing perverse and orthodox** (邪正),
**Revealing auspicious and inauspicious** (吉凶)—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**Digging wells** (凿井) **to draw clear water** (澹水),
**Boring fire** (钻火) **and carving wood** (难木),
**Melting metal and molding clay** (流金陶土),
To **blend the Five Refined Arts** (五美).
The **resources of the Five Refined Arts**,
To **nourish all bodies** (资百体)—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**Odd numbers** (奇) **measure yang**,
**Even numbers** (耦) **measure yin**,
**Odd and even** **pushed and performed**,
To **calculate all under Heaven**—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**Six beginnings** (六始) **as the laws** (律),
**Six intervals** (六间) **as the harmonics** (吕),
When **laws and harmonics** are **coordinated**,
The **twelve** are **tuned**,
And **daytime and nighttime** are **measured**—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**The Eighty-One Divisions** (八十一所) **of the states and families**,
**Marked as lower, middle, and upper**,
To **represent the Four Seas**—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

**One division** (一辟),
**Three ministers** (三公),
**Nine officials** (九卿),
**Twenty-seven great officers** (二十七大夫),
**Eighty-one elemental officials** (八十一元士)—
**Few govern the many**,
**None govern the nonexistent**—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

In ancient times, **there were no thunder sacrifices** (不霆) **nor divinations** (不虞),
(In some texts, *lèi* is read *yú* instead of *pèi*—
Sound: *yú*, others read *lèi*.)
**Slowing their contemplations** (慎其思虑),
**Not relying on fortune-telling or augury** (匪筮匪卜),
When **auspicious and inauspicious** **intermingled**,
The **sages** then **crafted the Yarrow Stalk and tortoise shell**,
**Piercing the essence** (钻精) **and leaning upon the spirit** (倚神),
**Clasping knowledge** (箝知) **of rest and auspice** (休咎)—
The Mysterious Dao **illuminates** it.

Thus, to **know what is unknowable**,
One **approximates it through the trigrams and hexagrams** (卦兆),
To **fathom depths and trace distances**,
One **seeks it through contemplation** (思虑).
Of these two, which **establishes the essence**?
The **essence** in **fortune-telling and divination**,
**The spirit moves its changes**;
The **essence** in **contemplation**,
**Plans align with their fittingness**;
The **essence** in **upright establishment**,
**None can overthrow it**;
The **essence** in **having what is guarded**,
**None can seize it**.
Thus, to **unravel the tangled threads** (抽天下之蔓蔓)
And **dispel the chaotic mixtures** (散天下之混混)
Under Heaven—
Who but the **essence** could accomplish this?

**Illuminating from self-measurement** (莹自度数),
**Radiant in all methods** (晖於诸法),
And **chiefly relying on the utmost precision** (至精者),
It **returns to the One**.

The **observers**,
**Value adherence to natural patterns** (循) **and embodying spontaneity** (体自然).
When their **adherence is vast**,
Then their **embodiment is robust** (壮);
When their **adherence is slight**,
Then their **embodiment is meager** (瘠).
When their **adherence is straight**,
Then their **embodiment is complete** (浑);
When their **adherence is crooked**,
Then their **embodiment is scattered** (散).
Thus, they **do not fear what they possess**,
Nor **force what they lack**.
Like the **body itself**,
**Adding causes excess** (赘),
**Removing causes deficiency** (亏).
Thus, **substance is guided by nature** (质斡),
**Embellishment by human affairs** (华藻)—
Can it be **augmented or diminished**?

(The original reads: *"华藻在乎人事也，其可损益与？"*
Some texts omit *人事*, reading instead: *"华藻其作其字"*—
The **allowance** and **yellowing** **are as they are**.)

The **One** is **used to trace beginnings** (摹始)
And **measure depths** (测深),
The **three threes** (三三) **to exhaust endings** (尽终)
And **reach the utmost heights** (极崇),
The **two twos** (二二) **to align affairs** (参事)
And **grasp the central way** (要中).
**Human affairs mirror this**,
**Dedicating to its work** (务其事)
**Not its words** (不务其辞),
**Multiplying its changes** (多其变)
**Not its forms** (不多其文).

**Without coordination**, its **intentions are unclear** (其指不详),
**Without centrality**, its **responses are narrow** (其应不博),
**Without completeness**, its **work is confined** (其事不散),
**Without depth**, its **meaning is unseen** (其意不见).
Thus, **forms reveal the substance** (文以见乎质),
**Words reveal the emotions** (辞以睹乎情).
By **observing its application of words**,
One **sees what its heart desires**.

Such are the **words of the Mysterious Dao**.
**Exalting the Nine Degrees** (九度):
**One-One** (一一),
**One-Two** (一二),
**One-One-Two** (一一二),
**Two-One** (二一),
**Two-Two** (二二),
**Two-Three** (二三),
**Three-One** (三一),
**Three-Two** (三二),
**Three-Three** (三三).

chunks.original_text: 一一、初也； 三三，上也； 二二，中也。 此自然不可损益之约也，象策数焉。 夫道有因有循，有革有化。 因而循之，与道神之； 革而化之，与时宜之。 故因而能革，天道乃得； 革而能因，天道乃驯。 夫物不因不生，不革不成。 故知因而不知革，物失其则； 知革而不知因，物失其均。 革之匪时，物失其基； 因之匪理，物丧其纪。 因革乎因革，国家之矩范也。 矩范之动，成败之效也。 变通者，玄之事也。 因象水木，革象金火。 立天之经，曰阴与阳； 形地之纬，曰从与横； 表人之行，曰晦与明。 阴阳曰合其判#9，阴阳、从横、晦明，丁、宋皆无曰字。 从横曰纬其经#10，晦明曰别其材。 阴阳，该极也； 经纬，所遇也； 晦明，质性也。 阳不阴，无与合其施； 经不纬，无以成其谊； 明不晦，无以别其德。 阴阳，所以抽啧也； 宋作极赜，啧与颐同。 诸本作抽。 从横，所以莹理也； 明晦，所以昭事也。 啧情也抽，理也许作抽情也。 莹，事也昭，君子之道也。 开而当名者，玄之辞也。 自中为阳，周为阴，以极八十一首。 九位在中，经纬相错，时物唯其所遇而见谊焉。 晦明之才，昼夜之事也。 往来熏熏，得亡之门。 夫何得何亡，得福而亡祸也。 天地福顺而祸逆，山川福庳而祸高，人道福正而祸邪。 故君子内正而外驯，每以下人，是以动得福而亡祸也。 福不丑不能生祸，祸不好不能成福。 丑好乎丑好，君子所以亶表也。 宋作君子之亶表。 夫福乐终而祸忧始。 天地所贵曰福，鬼神所佑曰福，人道所喜曰福； 其所贱恶皆日祸。 章、许作其所贱在恶，丁作其所在贱恶，宋作其所贱恶。 故恶福甚者其祸亢。 昼人之祸少，夜人之祸多。 昼夜散者，其祸福杂。 莹以昭事，使人知祸福之归者也。 昼人之祸少，纯於明也； 夜人之祸多，纯於晦也。 、昼夜散者，其祸福杂，则或晦或明，不纯故也。 太玄首测冲错摛茔注卷第七竟 #1道藏本《集注太玄经》仅一至六卷，为司马光集注。 本书七至十卷，据百子全书本《太玄经》补，为许翰注。 #2『公』原脱，据《十三经注疏》补。 #3『 』原作『阙』，据正文改。 #4『盛』原脱，据范本补。 #5#6#7『逿』原作『逖』，误也。 #8『有』原作『有有』，衍一字。 #9『曰』原作『日』，据范本改。 #10『纬其经』原作〔经其经』，据范本改。 太玄数卷第八 玄数 昆仑天地而产蓍，参珍睟精以 数。 ，《释文》音索，宋苏各切。 宋作二以 数，许、黄作三以 数，章、丁无二、三字。 散幽於三重而立家，旁拟两仪则睹事。 逢遭并合， 系其名，而极命焉。 ，《释文》音戛，陆作 ，宋作挥，今诸家皆作 。 精则经，疑之事其质乎？ 令曰假太玄。 假太玄孚贞，章及丁别本作假假太玄，丁、宋、许、黄作假太玄、假太玄。 爰质所疑，于神于灵。 休则逢阳，星时数辞从； 咎则逢阴，星时数辞违。 凡筮有道，不精不筮，不疑不筮，不轨不筮，不以其占若不筮。 神灵之曜曾越卓，章、许、黄神灵之三字复出。 三十有六而策视焉。 天以三分，终於六成，故十有八策。 天不施，地不成，因而倍之，地则虚三以扮天之十八也。 扮，房吻切。 诸本作扮天十八，宋有之字。 别一挂于左手之小指，中分其余。

**One-One** is the **beginning**; **Three-Three**, the **apex**; **Two-Two**, the **center**.
This is the **unalterable natural measure**—
a model for **divination’s calculations**.

The **Dao** has **roots and continuity**, **transformation and change**.
Following roots and continuity—**harmony with the Dao’s spirit**;
Transforming and changing—**adapting to the times**.
Thus, **rooted yet transformative**, the **Heavenly Dao is realized**;
**Transformative yet rooted**, the **Heavenly Dao is tamed**.

Things **do not arise without roots**, nor **fulfill without transformation**.
Thus, **knowing roots but not transformation**, things **lose their standard**;
**Knowing transformation but not roots**, things **lose their balance**.
Transformation **untimely**, things **lose their foundation**;
Roots **unprincipled**, things **lose their order**.

**Rooting and transforming**—
the **measures of statecraft**.
The **movement of measures**—
the **effects of success and failure**.

**Adaptability**—
the **mysteries of the Dao**.

Roots **mirror water and wood**,
Transformation **mirrors metal and fire**.

Establishing **Heaven’s threads**—
**Yin and Yang** are called;
Shaping **Earth’s weaves**—
**Compliance and Resistance** are called;
Manifesting **human conduct**—
**Obscurity and Clarity** are called.

**Yin and Yang**—**uniting their distinctions**;
**Compliance and Resistance**—**weaving the threads**;
**Obscurity and Clarity**—**discriminating their essence**.

Yin without Yang—**no union in application**;
Threads without weaves—**no fulfillment in meaning**;
Clarity without Obscurity—**no distinction in virtue**.

**Yin and Yang**—**to draw forth emotions**;
**Compliance and Resistance**—**to refine principles**;
**Obscurity and Clarity**—**to illuminate affairs**.

**Drawing emotions**—**the refined Dao**;
**Refining principles**—**the illuminated conduct**;
**Illuminating affairs**—**the path of the virtuous**.

**Opening to its name**—
the **mysteries’ speech**.

From the **center as Yang**, encircling as **Yin**,
to **extreme the eighty-one heads**.

Nine positions at the **center**,
threads and weaves intersecting—
things **manifest their meaning** as they encounter time.

**Obscurity and Clarity**—
the **matters of day and night**.

**Coming and going**, **permeating**—
entering the **Gate of Loss**.

**What is gained and what is lost**—
**gaining blessings, losing calamities**.

Heaven and Earth:
**Blessings align**, calamities **reverse**;
Mountains and rivers:
**Blessings settle low**, calamities **rise high**;
Human conduct:
**Blessings are upright**, calamities **are perverse**.

Thus, the **virtuous**—
**internally upright, externally tamed**,
**always yielding to others**—
therefore **their actions gain blessings and avoid calamities**.

Blessings **do not arise from ugliness**,
calamities **do not persist from goodness**.
**Ugliness and goodness**—
the **virtuous thus clearly distinguish**.

Blessings **end in joy**, calamities **begin in sorrow**.
What Heaven and Earth **value** is called **blessing**;
what **ghosts and spirits** **favor** is called **blessing**;
what **human conduct** **delights in** is called **blessing**;
what they **despise and abhor**—all are called **calamity**.

Thus, the **more one despises blessings**, the **greater the calamity**.
The **calamities of daytime** are few—**pure in clarity**;
the **calamities of night** are many—**pure in obscurity**.
Those **scattered between day and night**—
their **calamities and blessings mix**,
for they are **neither purely obscure nor purely clear**.

**Refining to illuminate affairs**—
to make people **know the return of calamities and blessings**.

---
**太玄数卷第八 玄数**

**Kunlun**—**Heaven and Earth’s birthplace**—**produces the stalks**,
**three sacred essences** **refined**—**to number**.

Dispersing the **mysterious in three layers** to establish **families**,
**comparing the Two Principles** to **perceive affairs**.

**Encounters and unions**—
**naming their patterns** and **extending their command**.

**Precision**—**the threads of doubt**—**its substance revealed**.
**The Oracle says**: *"Assume the Great Mysteries"*.

**Assuming the Great Mysteries**—**truth and sincerity**,
**doubting the substance**—**divine and spirit-like**.

**Rest**—**encountering Yang**, stars and times **align in speech**;
**Blame**—**encountering Yin**, stars and times **contradict in speech**.

**Divination has its Dao**:
**Without precision, do not divinate**,
**without doubt, do not divinate**,
**without order, do not divinate**,
**without its omens, do not divinate as if divining**.

**Divine brilliance**—**soaring beyond** (three characters repeated).
**Thirty-six**—**the stalks are viewed**.

Heaven **divides by three**, completing **six**—
thus **eighteen stalks**.

Heaven **does not act alone**, Earth **does not complete alone**—
**doubling their roots**, Earth **lacks three** to **match Heaven’s eighteen**.

**Separate one** and hang it **on the left small finger**,
**dividing the rest in half**.

chunks.original_text: 以三搜之，并余於艻。 艻，与扐同。 一艻之后，再数其余，七为一，八为二，九为三，六算而策道穷也。 逢有下、中、上：下，思也； 中，福也； 上，祸也。 思、福、祸各有下、中、上，以昼夜别其休咎焉。 天以三分，则一二三综而为六。 以六因三，为十有八。 天施而地成之，是以倍为三十有六。 此神灵曜曾越卓之数也。 地则虚三以受天，故策用三十有三。 玄筮挂一者，至精也； 中分而三搜之者，至变也； 余一二三则并於艻者，归奇也。 一艻而复数其余，卒观或．七或八或九，则昼一二三焉。 天以六成，故六算而策道穷，则数极而象足也。 得方求州，得州求部，得部求家，是谓散幽於三重而立家，凡四 。 极一为二，极二为三，极三为推，推三为嬴赞。 章、许及丁别本作推三为赢赞。 嬴或作赢，盖通。 赞嬴入表，表嬴入家，家嬴入部，部嬴入州，州嬴入方，范注：玄，或作去。 陆云； 当作玄。 今诸家作玄，唯宋作去，章作入玄。 数自玄生，衍极而复归於玄。 此圣人同民吉凶，所以洗心于密者也，故间於筮法之中。 昔者禹别九州，任土作贡，而锡尧玄圭，告厥成功，盖以象此。 一从、二从、三从，是谓大休； 一从、二从、三违，始、中休，终咎； 一从、二违、三违，始休，中、终咎； 一违、二从、三从，始咎，中、终休； 一违、二违、三从，始、中咎，终休； 一违、二违、三违，是谓大咎。 占有四，或星，或时，或数，或辞。 旦则用经，夕则用纬。 观始、中，决从终。 昼为休，夜为咎。 而又以星时数辞，和乖盛衰，义类相取而占其事。 旦用经，一五七； 夕用纬，三四八； 旦夕之中，二经一纬，用二六九。 是谓三表。 旦象天，夕象地，中象人也。 一五六也进乎七，三四七也进乎八，二六八也进乎九。 观始中，决从终者，考积之极，而要其变也。 是故余艻之数，一兆七，三兆八，二兆九也。 占有终休而反咎，有终咎而反休者，要在审观所质之事，以星时数参之而已矣。 非忠信之事，吉而更以凶，此占法也。 三八为木，为东方，为春。 日甲乙，辰寅卯。 声角，色青，味酸，臭膻，形诎信。 生火，胜土。 时生，藏脾。 肺极上以覆肾，极下以潜心，居中央以象君德，而左脾右肝，承之以位五行。 《月令》春祭先脾，夏祭先肺，中央祭先心，秋祭先肝，冬祭先肾，此玄符也。 是故肺藏气者，火也； 肾藏精者，水也； 心藏神者，土也； 脾藏思者，木也； 肝藏血者，金也。 其为体也，则脾土、肺金、心火、肝木、肾水； 其为位也，则丫养育而臣制畜。 不与物合者，一而已矣，玄德之象也。 存志音存，或作存。 木存志者，立也； 金存魄者，营也； 火存魂者，变也； 水存精者，潜也； 土存神者，化也。 志，水也，而存於木； 魄，土也，而存於金； 魂，木也，而存於火； 神，火也，而存於土。 皆托乎其所生。 《老子》所谓弱其志，强其骨，虚其心，实其腹者是已。 唯精一之至也，是以其为物不贰也。 性仁，情喜。 事貌，用恭，撝肃，征旱。 《洪范》庶征，雨旸取纬，燠寒风取经。 玄数分类，则以其正言而已矣，弗以冲气相通也。 帝太吴，神勾芒，星从其位。 氏、房、心、尾、箕，位寅卯。 类为鳞，为雷，为鼓，为恢声，为新，为躁，为户，为牖。
chunks.translated_text:
With three stalks gathered, the remainder is grouped under **艻** [same as *扐*].
After one **艻**, recount the rest in sevens—seven as one, eight as two, nine as three—
thus six counts exhaust the **stalks’ Dao**.

**Encountering** has **lower, middle, upper**:
Lower is **thought**,
Middle is **fortune**,
Upper is **calamity**.
Thought, fortune, and calamity each have lower, middle, upper—
by day and night, their **rest and blame** are distinguished.

Heaven divides by three, thus one, two, three **weave into six**.
Multiply six by three to make **eighteen**.
Heaven acts, Earth completes it—
thus doubled, they form **thirty-six**.
This is the **divine brilliance**—**soaring beyond** (three characters repeated).

Earth lacks three to match Heaven’s eighteen—
thus the stalks use **thirty-three**.

The **Mysterious Divination** hangs one stalk—**most precise**;
dividing and gathering three times—**most variable**;
grouping the remainder under **艻**—**returning to the odd**.

After one **艻**, recounting the rest yields seven, eight, or nine—
thus day’s one, two, three.

Heaven completes six, so six counts exhaust the **stalks’ Dao**—
numbers reach their limit, symbols find their fullness.

Obtain **direction**, seek **province**, obtain **department**, seek **house**—
this is **dispersing the obscure through three layers** and establishing **house**—**fourfold**.

Extreme one becomes two, extreme two becomes three, extreme three becomes **推** [*tuī*],
**推** three becomes **嬴赞** [*yíngzàn*].
*Chapter, Xu*, and *Ding* variants read **推** three as **赢赞**—
*嬴* or *赢* are interchangeable.
*赞嬴* enters **表**, *表嬴* enters **家**, *家嬴* enters **部**, *部嬴* enters **州**, *州嬴* enters **方**.
*Fàn Zhǔ* notes: *玄* may be *去* [omitted].
*Lù Yún* says: Should read *玄*.
Now all versions read *玄*, except *Sòng* as *去*, *Chapter* as *入玄*.
Numbers arise from *玄*, extend to extremes, then return to *玄*.
This is how the Sage harmonizes the people’s **fortune and calamity**,
washing the heart in secrecy—
thus interspersed within the **divination method**.

In ancient times, **Yú** divided the nine provinces,
assigned tributes by soil, and bestowed upon **Yáo** the **black jade tablet**,
declaring his success—
symbolizing this very principle.

**One follows, two follow, three follow**—**Great Rest**.
**One follows, two follow, three contradict**—
beginning and middle **Rest**, ending in **blame**.
**One follows, two contradict, three contradict**—
beginning **Rest**, middle and end **blame**.
**One contradicts, two follow, three follow**—
beginning **blame**, middle and end **Rest**.
**One contradicts, two contradict, three follow**—
beginning and middle **blame**, ending in **Rest**.
**One contradicts, two contradict, three contradict**—**Great Blame**.

Divination has four aspects: **stars, times, numbers, speech**.
Morning uses **classics**, evening uses **weft**.
Observe beginning and middle, decide by the end.
Day signifies **Rest**, night signifies **blame**.
And by **stars, times, numbers, speech**—
harmony or contradiction,盛衰—
their categories align to determine the matter.

Morning uses **classics**: one, five, seven;
Evening uses **weft**: three, four, eight;
Morning and evening combined: two **classics**, one **weft**, using two, six, nine—
this is the **three tables**.
Morning symbolizes **Heaven**, evening **Earth**, the middle **Human**.

One, five, six advance to **seven**,
Three, four, seven advance to **eight**,
Two, six, eight advance to **nine**.
Observing beginning and middle, deciding by the end—
examining accumulated extremes and grasping their changes.

Thus the remaining **艻** numbers:
One portends **seven**, three portends **eight**, two portends **nine**.

Divination may yield **ending Rest but reversing blame**,
or **ending blame but reversing Rest**—
it depends on carefully observing the questioned matter,
cross-referencing with **stars, times, numbers**.

If not a matter of **loyalty and sincerity**, fortune may shift to misfortune—
this is the **divination law**.

**Three eights** are **Wood**, the **East**, **Spring**.
Days: **Jia, Yi**; hours: **Yín, Mǎo**.
Sound: **Jué (角)**, color: **green**, taste: **sour**, odor: **rancid**, form: **bent and trustworthy**.
Generates **Fire**, overcomes **Earth**.
Seasonally generates, stores in the **spleen**.
The **lung** extends upward to cover the **kidney**,
descends low to conceal the **heart**,
resides centrally to embody **sovereign virtue**,
while **spleen (left)** and **liver (right)** support the **Five Phases** in position.

*The Monthly Ordinances* decree:
Spring sacrifices to the **spleen**, summer to the **lung**,
Central (autumn?) sacrifices to the **heart**, autumn to the **liver**,
Winter to the **kidney**—
this is the **Mysterious Correspondence**.

Thus the **lung** stores **qi**—**Fire**;
the **kidney** stores **essence**—**Water**;
the **heart** stores **spirit**—**Earth**;
the **spleen** stores **thought**—**Wood**;
the **liver** stores **blood**—**Metal**.

As **bodies**, they are:
**Spleen (Earth)**, **Lung (Metal)**, **Heart (Fire)**, **Liver (Wood)**, **Kidney (Water)**;
As **positions**, they **nourish and govern**, **minister and domesticate**.

Not aligning with others—**one alone**—
the **Mysterious Virtue’s** symbol.

**Preserve intent (志)**, **preserve sound (音)** [or *store*].
Wood preserves **intent**—**uprightness**;
Metal preserves **ether (魄)**—**campaigning**;
Fire preserves **soul (魂)**—**transformation**;
Water preserves **essence**—**concealment**;
Earth preserves **spirit**—**transmutation**.
**Intent** is **Water**, yet stored in **Wood**;
**Ether** is **Earth**, yet stored in **Metal**;
**Soul** is **Wood**, yet stored in **Fire**;
**Spirit** is **Fire**, yet stored in **Earth**.
All entrust themselves to their **generative source**.

As *Laozi* says:
*"Weaken the intent, strengthen the bones,
empty the heart, fill the belly."*
Only the **perfectly unified** remain undivided.

**Nature** is **benevolence**, **emotion** is **joy**.
**Affairs** appear **proper**, **conduct** is **reverent**,
**solemn**, **austere**, **drought**.
*The Hong Fan* records:
*"Rain and drought follow weft,
heat and cold, wind follow classics."*

**Mysterious numbers** classify by their **true names** alone—
not by **clashing qi** intermingling.

**Emperor Tàiwú**, **God Gōumáng**—
**stars** follow their positions.
**Shì, Fáng, Xīn, Wěi, Jī**—
positions **Yín, Mǎo**.
Their **categories** include:
**scales**, **thunder**, **drums**, **resounding sound**, **novelty**, **restlessness**, **door**, **window**.

chunks.original_text: 甲象为鳞，秩秩次比众盛。 盖极则震而变为雷，为鼓，为恢声。 发生为新，决塞为躁。 大者为户而出，小者为牖而通也。 凡物，出必由户，入必由门。 户，奇也； 门，偶也。 灶惕以养，而行流通。 中溜土，以冲虚函天明，受众流。 此福所集，故家主之。 门户阖辟有变，纬也； 灶行中溜有常，经也。 是故《月令》：春祀户，夏祀灶，中央祀中溜，秋祀门，冬祀行。 类求五物，与玄合符。 为嗣，为承。 为叶，为绪。 震为长子之变也。 为户、牖，则家立矣。 为赦，为解。 为多子。 税枯释甲，震之功也，国事象焉。 萌生孕字，时物方昌。 为出，为予。 帝出乎震，布德施惠，而物象之。 为赦为解，出而予也。 为竹为草，为果为实。 秀拔而为竹，滋蔓而为草，首敛而为果，皆木气也。 果为实，象果则将复生焉。 为鱼。 水生鳞属，蕃息之象。 竹草至鱼，皆多子类也。 为疏器。 《月令》：春则其器疏以达。 刻而镂之，象土之发生无所塞也。 疏器，致人力焉，以相天时。 为田，为规。 许、黄作为规为田，宋、郭作为田为规。 木治土。 为田，木用事而稷官展采焉。 为规，象元之运木。 土稽之木上，象致力于春，以相天物者也。 为矛。 句兵曲直不杀。 戈氏罇，矛氏镦。 矛敦，仁也。 为青怪。 以正治国，以奇用兵。 五行反常，则各以其物见异焉。 为鼽。 音求。 春行秋令，则人多鼽，金沴木也。 为狂。 弗恭弗肃，动荡之过。 四九为金，为西方，为秋。 日庚辛，辰申酉。 声商，色白，味辛，臭腥，形革。 生水，胜木。 时杀，藏肝，存魄。 性谊，情怒。 事言，用从，撝乂。 征雨。 帝少吴，神蓐收，星从其位。 胃、昴、毕、氏、参，位申酉。 类为毛。 金革火而收之，其气发散。 为毛，庚辛象也。 为医，为巫祝，为猛。 唐人避讳，书多改虎为猛。 此字疑当作虎，而未有本证定。 为旧，为鸣。 医攻疾，巫祝被不详，皆善革者也。 为猛，盖虎，甲毛类也。 虎变异龙，因旧而炳。 凡物坚成则鸣，如虎啸风，鸣之盛也。 医之革物，使复旧常，而巫祝善鸣矣。 物正为新，物老为旧。 凡动，木也。 凡声，金也。 动夬为躁，声扬为鸣。 鸣尚节焉。 为门，为山，为限，为边，为城，为骨，为石。 以坚立节，故为门，为山，为限，为边，为城。 金以方止。 边，四方也。 城，四营之，以为险。 故外象为限，为边，为城。 内象为骨。 骨自坚生，此木气也。 而凡物之坚，皆金为之，故木质皆白。 金类为骨，其极为石。 为环佩，为首饰，为重宝，为大哆，丁、宋无此一句。 为扣器。 扣，音口，金饰器口也。 疑极而说见，质定而文生之。 环佩，身之节也。 加尊而为首饰，又加贵而为重宝。 环佩象四，首饰象九。 重宝体觉德焉。 《说文》侈，大。 哆，口之兑也。 扣器以金饰口，致说焉，亦以立坚。 为舂，为椎。 为力，为县。 与悬同。 为燧，为兵，为械。 为齿，为角，为螫，为毒。 政饰以说，而小过治之。 扣器以受生。 为舂，为椎，为力，以坚胜也。 力胜，而后能胜物。 县之，县以权，制其变。 故以金变火为燧，又火变金为兵。 其变如此，七九错也。 人有兵械，物有齿、角、螫、毒，皆以胜物而立我焉。 立我已甚，则可入可取，寇贼生之。 为狗，为入，为取，为 。
chunks.translated_text:
「The **Tàixiàng** (甲象) scales as **lín** (鳞),
in orderly ranks, their abundance grows.
When pushed to their utmost, they **zhèn** (震) and transform into **léi** (雷)—thunder,
into **gǔ** (鼓)—drums,
into **huīshēng** (恢声)—resounding echoes.

Their emergence marks **xīn** (新)—novelty,
their obstruction yields **zào** (躁)—restlessness.
The grand becomes **hù** (户)—door, and exits,
the small becomes **yǒu** (牖)—window, and flows through.
All things:
to exit, they must pass through **hù** (户),
to enter, they must pass through **mén** (门).
**Hù** (户) is **odd** (奇),
**mén** (门) is **even** (偶).

The **zào** (灶) stove and **tì** (惕) hearth nurture by **liú** (流通)—circulation,
while the **zhōngliú** (中溜) central hearth
**chōng** (冲) and **xū** (虚) to clear the **hán** (函)—enclosure,
illuminating **tiān** (天)—Heaven,
and receiving all **liú** (流).
Thus, this **fú** (福)—blessing is gathered,
and the family master presides over it.

When doors and stoves open and close in change,
this is **wéi** (纬)—the **subtle, responsive** (纬) principle;
when the stove’s circulation and central hearth maintain constancy,
this is **jīng** (经)—the **fundamental, enduring** (经) principle.

Therefore, *The Yueling* (月令) states:
*"In spring, sacrifice to the **hù** (户)—door;
in summer, sacrifice to the **zào** (灶)—stove;
in the center, sacrifice to the **zhōngliú** (中溜)—central hearth;
in autumn, sacrifice to the **mén** (门)—gate;
in winter, sacrifice to the **xíng** (行)—circulation."*

Their **categories** (类) align with the **Wǔwù** (五物)—five elements,
harmonizing with the **Mysterious Numbers** (玄).
To **sì** (嗣)—inherit,
to **chéng** (承)—uphold,
to **yè** (叶)—follow,
to **xù** (绪)—continue.
**Zhèn** (震) as the **chángzǐ** (长子)—eldest son’s transformation.

To become **hù** (户) and **yǒu** (牖),
then the family is established.
To **shè** (赦)—pardon,
to **jiě** (解)—release,
and to bear **duōzǐ** (多子)—many offspring.
The **shuì** (税) of witheredness and the **jiè** (枯) of decay,
the **shì** (释) of shedding and the **jiǎ** (甲) of scales—
these are the **zhèn** (震) element’s functions,
mirrored in state affairs.

**Méngshēng** (萌生) sprouting and **yùnzì** (孕字) bearing—
the season’s bounty flourishes.
To **chū** (出)—emerge,
to **yǔ** (予)—bestow.
The **Emperor** (帝) emerges from **zhèn** (震),
spreading **virtue/power** (德) and **bestowing benevolence** (施惠),
while all things take form accordingly.
To **shè** (赦)—pardon and **jiě** (解)—release,
is to emerge and bestow.

To **zhú** (竹)—bamboo and **cǎo** (草)—grass,
to **guǒ** (果)—fruit and **shí** (实)—kernel.
**Xiùbá** (秀拔) refined and **pú** (拔) towering, they become **zhú** (竹)—bamboo;
**zīmàn** (滋蔓) spreading and **wàn** (蔓) creeping, they become **cǎo** (草)—grass.
**Shǒuliǎn** (首敛) concentrated at the head, they become **guǒ** (果)—fruit,
all **mùqì** (木气)—wood **qi**.
Fruit becomes **shí** (实)—kernel,
and the kernel’s form suggests rebirth.

To become **yú** (鱼)—fish:
water nurtures **línshǔ** (鳞属)—scaled creatures,
a symbol of **fánxī** (蕃息)—proliferation and growth.
From bamboo and grass to fish,
all belong to the **duōzǐ** (多子)—many offspring category.

To become **shūqì** (疏器)—perforated vessels.
*The Yueling* (月令) states:
*"In spring, their vessels are perforated to allow passage."*
**Kè** (刻) carved and **lòu** (镂) hollowed,
symbolizing the **tǔ** (土) element’s unrestricted emergence.
Perforated vessels **zhì** (致) harness human effort
to correspond with **tiānshí** (天时)—Heaven’s seasons.

To become **tián** (田)—field and **guī** (规)—boundary:
**Xǔ** (许) and **Huáng** (黄) as boundaries form fields,
**Sòng** (宋) and **Guō** (郭) as fields define boundaries.
**Mù** (木) governs **tǔ** (土).
To become **tián** (田)—field,
**mù** (木) takes charge, and the **jìguān** (稷官) officials expand their cultivation.
To become **guī** (规)—boundary,
it mirrors the **yuán** (元) principle’s **yùnmù** (运木)—circulation of wood.
**Tǔ** (土) rests upon the wood’s **jī** (稽)—foundation,
symbolizing the exertion of effort in spring
to harmonize with Heaven’s bounty.

To become **máo** (矛)—spear:
**Jùbīng** (句兵) weapons bend without piercing.
**Gēshì** (戈氏) **yīn** (罇) and **máoshì** (矛氏) **tuì** (镦).
The **máo** (矛) is **dūn** (敦)—thick, symbolizing **rén** (仁)—benevolence.
To become **qīngguài** (青怪)—strange and green:
**Zhèng** (正) governs the state,
**qí** (奇) is used in warfare.
When the **Wǔxíng** (五行)—five elements
**fǎncháng** (反常)—reverse their usual order,
each displays its **yì** (异)—unusual aspect.

To become **bì** (鼽)—nasal congestion:
**yīnqiú** (音求)—sound seeks resonance.
When **spring’s xíng** (行) overlaps with **autumn’s lìng** (令),
people suffer **bì** (鼽)—nasal congestion,
as **jīn** (金) **zhì** (沴) overcomes **mù** (木).
To become **kuáng** (狂)—madness:
**fúgōngfúsù** (弗恭弗肃)—lacking reverence and solemnity,
the excess of **dòngdàng** (动荡)—turbulence.
**Sìjiǔ** (四九) the **fourth phase of the ninth month** (四九) corresponds to **jīn** (金),
to the **west** (西方),
to **autumn** (秋).
**Dì** (日) **gēngxīn** (庚辛),
**shènyǒuxiǔ** (辰申酉).
**Shēngshāng** (声商)—sound of the **Shāng** (商) tone,
**sèbái** (色白)—white hue,
**wèixīn** (味辛)—pungent flavor,
**xiùxīng** (臭腥)—fishy odor,
**xínggé** (形革)—leathery form.
It **shēng** (生) produces **water** (水),
**shèng** (胜) overcomes **wood** (木).
**Shíkè** (时杀)—seasonal restraint,
**cánggān** (藏肝)—conceals the liver,
**cúnpò** (存魄)—preserves the **pò** (魄)—etheric soul.
**Xìngyì** (性谊)—nature of **yì** (谊)—harmony,
**qíngnù** (情怒)—passion of anger.
**Shìyán** (事言)—affairs of speech,
**yòngcóng** (用从)—conduct of compliance,
**sùyì** (撝乂)—solemn and **yì** (乂)—restrained.
**Zhèngyǔ** (征雨)—summons rain.
**Dìshǎowú** (帝少吴),
**Shénsuǎnshōu** (神蓐收),
**xīngcóngqìwèi** (星从其位)—stars follow their positions.
**Wèi, Mǎo, Bì, Shì, Shēn** (胃、昴、毕、氏、参),
**wèishēnyǒuxiǔ** (位申酉).
Their **categories** (类) include **máo** (毛)—hair.
**Jīn** (金) **géhuǒ** (革火)—transforms fire,
and **shōu** (收)—concentrates it,
its **qì** (气) disperses and spreads.
To become **máo** (毛)—hair,
**gēngxīn** (庚辛) **xiàng** (象)—symbolism prevails.
To become **yī** (医)—physician,
**wūzhù** (巫祝)—shaman and diviner,
and **měng** (猛)—fierce.
**Tángrén** (唐人) avoided taboo,
often rewriting **hǔ** (虎)—tiger as **měng** (猛).
This character likely should be **hǔ** (虎),
though no original text confirms it.

To become **jiù** (旧)—old,
and **míng** (鸣)—sound.
**Yī** (医) attacks **jí** (疾)—illness,
**wūzhù** (巫祝) invoke the **bèibùxiǎng** (被不详)—unclear mysteries,
both skilled in **gé** (革)—transformation.
To become **měng** (猛)—fierce,
it is **hǔ** (虎)—tiger,
a **jiǎmáo** (甲毛) category of scales and hair.
The **hǔ** (虎) tiger transforms into **yìlóng** (异龙)—strange dragon,
its **jīnjiù** (因旧) reliance on the old
brings **bǐng** (炳)—radiance.
All things, once fully formed, **míng** (鸣)—resound,
as the tiger’s roar echoes through the wind—
the **shèng** (盛)—peak of sound.
The physician’s **gé** (革)—transformative work
restores the **jiù** (旧)—old order,
while shamans and diviners excel in **míng** (鸣)—resonance.
When things are **zhèng** (正)—proper, they mark **xīn** (新)—new;
when things are **lǎo** (老)—aged, they mark **jiù** (旧)—old.
All movement is **mù** (木)—wood,
all sound is **jīn** (金)—metal.
**Dòngjiá** (动夬) turbulent movement becomes **zào** (躁)—restlessness,
**shēngyáng** (声扬) resonant sound becomes **míng** (鸣)—resonance.
Resonance upholds **jié** (节)—order.
To become **mén** (门)—gate,
**shān** (山)—mountain,
**xiàn** (限)—boundary,
**biān** (边)—edge,
**chéng** (城)—wall,
**gǔ** (骨)—bone,
and **shí** (石)—stone:
with **firmness** (坚) and **establishing order** (立节),
they become **mén** (门)—gate,
**shān** (山)—mountain,
**xiàn** (限)—boundary,
**biān** (边)—edge,
**chéng** (城)—wall.
**Jīn** (金) restrains with **fāng** (方)—rectangle.
**Biān** (边) are the **sìfāng** (四方)—four directions,
**chéng** (城) the **sìyíng** (四营)—fortified enclosures,
to create **xiǎn** (险)—defense.
Thus, externally they symbolize **xiàn** (限)—boundary,
**biān** (边)—edge,
and **chéng** (城)—wall.
Internally, they symbolize **gǔ** (骨)—bone.
Bone arises from **firmness** (坚),
this is **mùqì** (木气)—wood **qi**.
Yet all things’ **firmness** (坚) is shaped by **jīn** (金),
so wood’s essence is **bái** (白)—white.
The **jīn** (金) category becomes **gǔ** (骨)—bone,
its extreme is **shí** (石)—stone.

To become **huánpèi** (环佩)—ornaments,
**shǒushì** (首饰)—head adornments,
**zhòngbǎo** (重宝)—precious treasures,
and **dàduō** (大哆)—great **duō** (哆).
*(Note: The **Dīng** (丁) and **Sòng** (宋) versions omit this line.)*

To become **kòuqì** (扣器)—vessels with metal-rimmed mouths.
**Kòu** (扣), pronounced as **kǒu** (口),
adorns vessels’ mouths with **jīn** (金)—metal.
*(Note: Likely the **extreme** (极) of firmness and **shuō** (说)—appeasement,
with **quality** (质) set and **ornament** (文) arising.)*
**Huánpèi** (环佩) are the **jié** (节)—nodes of the body.
**Shǒushì** (首饰) adorn the head,
**zhòngbǎo** (重宝) signify **guì** (贵)—nobility.
**Huánpèi** (环佩) symbolize **sì** (四)—four,
**shǒushì** (首饰) symbolize **jiǔ** (九)—nine.
**Zhòngbǎo** (重宝) embody **juédé** (觉德)—enlightened virtue.
*The Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文) defines **chǐ** (侈) as **dà** (大)—great,
**duō** (哆) as the **duì** (兑)—mouth’s opening.
**Kòuqì** (扣器) adorn vessels’ mouths with metal,
**zhì** (致) to **shuō** (说)—appeasement,
also to **firmness** (立坚).
To become **chōng** (舂)—pestle,
**zhuī** (椎)—mallet,
**lì** (力)—strength,
and **xiàn** (县)—suspend.
*(Note: **Xiàn** (县) is synonymous with **xuán** (悬)—hang.)*
To become **suì** (燧)—flint,
**bīng** (兵)—weapon,
and **xiè** (械)—tool.
To become **chǐ** (齿)—teeth,
**jiǎo** (角)—horns,
**shì** (螫)—sting,
and **dú** (毒)—venom.
**Zhèngshì** (政饰) governs with **shuō** (说)—appeasement,
and **xiǎoguò** (小过) restrains minor excesses.
**Kòuqì** (扣器) receives **shēng** (生)—life.
To become **chōng** (舂)—pestle,
**zhuī** (椎)—mallet,
and **lì** (力)—strength,
to **firmness** (坚) and **shèng** (胜)—overcome.
**Lìshèng** (力胜)—strength overcomes,
then one can **shèng** (胜)—overcome things.
**Xiànzhì** (县之), **xiàn** (县) suspends with **quán** (权)—authority,
**zhì** (制) controlling its **biàn** (变)—trans

**Mysterious numbers** classify by their **true names** alone—
